description:
My 21st century voice kept forgetting to "speak easy," as my raucous laughter and attempts to speak over the music were met with a couple of friendly, in-character reprimands by Speakeasy staff. Oops!

I'm costume averse, shying away from Halloween parties. But it was easy to find "flapper" style dresses on Amazon, and mine was under $40. I am not ever comfortable wearing a costume, but I quickly learned to appreciate my period dress, as I was then part of the 1920s scene, just like everyone else.

I loved stepping down into the Speakeasy. It was like going into another era, for sure. The set design was well done, as if we were on a real set in a professional play. Performances were top-notch. I was so impressed by the acting, especially by the showgirls in their dressing room, whom we watched through a two-way mirror - bravo, bravo! 

I felt a bit like the Ebenezer, when visiting Christmases past and future. It was like walking among people who don't see you, but in a good way.

All our phones had been locked up, so no one was checking into Facebook or Yelping or taking selfies for Instagram, and that helped to keep the experience more authentic. The only thing I missed was not knowing the time (since phones were locked up and mine was in coat check) and we had to be outside to catch our ride home at a certain time. I recommend wearing a (non-Smart) watch.

I'm not a drinker so being at a Speakeasy was kind of daunting for me. I would have loved a coffee!

Not much offerings by way of food at the Speakeasy, so we snuck out early and had a quick meal of freshly made dim sum right next door at China Live. 

The Speakeasy was immersive and fun. Give it a try!
author: Shannon M.

description:
WOW. This was an incredible experience. I highly recommend this for anyone who has even the slightest bit of love for the 1920's. 

So much better than I could ever hope for and I can't wait to come back!
The immersive nature of this place is no joke, and they paid attention to so many tiny details that really made me feel like I traveled back in time - almost felt like a dream...

At first, I expected all of the acting to be somewhat cheesy but a few of the scenes that we encountered really had me engaged and lost in the drama. 

I know they have become a little bit more lax on the dress code recently, but honestly the costumes are half of the immersive experience so I highly recommend going in costume.
author: Hanna S.

description:
If you've been to Sleep No More and you are expecting a similar experience here, read on. Long story short, it's pretty different. 

I'm one of the people who were swept off their feet by Sleep No More and due to the excellent experience there, became interested in the Speakeasy. In its essence, both shows fall in the same category of immersive theater, but otherwise, to me at least, the experience is very different.

For one, Sleep No More's main story arch is more a combination of horror and intrigue as compared to The Speakeasy, which falls more in the genre of historical fiction. If you enjoy solving mysteries and occasionally elements of horror, you won't really find that at The Speakeasy. However, you will find more straightforward story lines and humor, lots and lots of jokes. They are more keen to make you laugh and have a good time then to scare you. The most scary/twisted scenes are nothing compared to ones in Sleep No More (which are more raw and disturbing)

The Speakeasy performance also focuses more on character interactions. They really make sure you feel as if you a part of the world in which the actors dwell. The actors will often try to make eye contact, ask you questions, get you involved, whereas in the Sleep No More, very rarely do actors interact with you, and for the most part as a viewer, you act as imaginary observers of their world, not participants in them, which was the case in the Speakeasy where Actors were actively aware of your existence.

Sleep No More also features a mix of interpretative dancing and acting, but not so much singing. (at least from what I recall) There is a lot of singing and dancing at the Speakeasy, but nothing as abstract as interpretative dancing. 

Some other differences include the fact that scenes don't shift over time at the Speakeasy. In Sleep No More, scenes often change, things gets moved around, the same area you visited before, could look very different when you visit it again. Additionally, there is much more ground covered in the Sleep No More show as compared to the Speakeasy, which features ~6-7 main areas. It took my bf and I very little time to discover all the areas, after that we kept on expecting more rooms or areas to open up, but they didn't, which made the exploration part kind of boring.

This is solely my experience however, my BF preferred the Speakeasy more to his Sleep No More experience which he found to be too abstract. Overall, I'm just happy that more of this style of entertainment is available!

P.S. As other people wrote in their reviews, don't get the premium tickets. They don't offer much additional except small complimentary drinks. Other than that, the "premium" seating is not that useful. We were placed too awkwardly in the front in the bar and it actually made it even more difficult to enjoy the show as they stuffed us to share a table with another couple right next to the piano area. I had to crane my neck backwards to see what was going on. Probably was better to actually sit further back.
author: Sherica L.

description: Cool experience for people to try. The space is small, however, so it can get old/boring pretty quick once you've seen each room. The gambling isn't for real money. Not sure how there are pictures of inside (the ones from customers) on Yelp, but they no longer allow phones inside and you're required to turn it off in front of them and put it in a pouch.There's a photo booth inside but it was broken when we went so we couldn't take any pictures. The waitress at cabaret show never came by to take our drink order so we had to wave someone else down to take our order, which ended up being close to the end of the show. The actors were pretty good. Lots of drama throughout entire story line. I'd go back to show a friend, but not for my own entertainment.
author: Natasha K.

description: Wow! What an incredible experience! Impressive immersive theater! Went with a group of 9 friends and we all had SO much fun, even better than I had dreamed it would be. Get your costumes from Amazon (so cheap, but beautiful!) and grab a drink beforehand from a close by bar. Be ready to immerse yourself in the eye candy!!
author: Mr. And Mrs. G.

description:
The Speakeasy is epic! I had an amazing time. The whole thing was so much fun. From getting dressed up like a flapper to the very end of the night. I highly recommend dressing up in the 1920's attire. This was a pretty pricey deal though. We paid like $300 for a table for the entire night ($100/hr), plus $75 for drinks, $100 for renting costumes, and $35 for the optional photo. First off, we did NOT rent costumes from them so I have no idea what the rates are here. We got a male (gangster) and a female (flapper) from a dance store in San Rafael (total for both was $100). I highly recommend getting the picture. The photographer will pose you, take a few shots and hook you up with the best one. This is great since you can't bring a phone (which I loved not seeing cell phones everywhere). That would've absolutely ruined it for me. I think the table was unnecessary, tbh. Although it was nice to have a place to come back and sit down every once in a while. I don't recommend wearing high heels if you're not used to walking around in them. I made that mistake and wouldn't wish it upon my worst enemy. Every time we came back to sit at the table, I noticed we could just sit wherever there was a free one and no one checked if we paid for it or for how long. I'm pretty sure anyone can just sit wherever. At the beginning of the night there was the most people watching the show in the cabaret. During that time it would be good to have a table reserved. The show went on for the whole time we were there. The performers were great, and really gave it an authentic feel. I really felt like this is exactly what it would've been like to go to a speakeasy back in the day. I can't judge the food or drinks because I just had water. I did peek at the menu and it was mostly appetizers and drinks. They did have like one sandwich I think. It did not look like people come here for the food. I didn't see much and we went out to dinner before. 
We did arrive fashionably late because we missed their last email giving us instructions on how to get in. So, we ended up going to the location marked here on Yelp and it was way off. I'm pretty sure they don't want their exact location disclosed and they were very secretive about the whole thing. That slightly complicated things but added to the authentic vibe. Overall, the performers and everyone who we came across went out of their way to make this fun and as realistic as possible. I will absolutely go again!
author: Sylvia L.

description: Fun! I would describe this as an immersive, interactive play. This is great for all ages. There were several people there by themselves just to watch the characters, and several there who mentioned it wasn't their first time. For those organizing groups- We had some issues with everyone buying their own tickets so I'd maybe buy everyone's tickets and have them Venmo me next time. Kristen was AMAZING for helping to sort everything out. Everyone was wowed when we walked around and got pulled in for special things. I'd always kind of have a meeting point to get back to if you're trying to coordinate. The man on the moon picture only holds eight people so we split our group up for photos. Also, may want to let your guests know this is not a true bar experience- speaking quiet is really encouraged- and the goal is not to get drunk but slightly tipsy. Also- tip for this with medical devices connected to your phone, remember to bring another monitor so they can take your phone. We went to Tamarind Hall (walking) before and they were not able to get us within 1 h and 20 mins so get there extra early, we went to 15 romolo after- which was perfect and you can make a table reservation there.  From beginning to end the staff was super helpful!
author: Niekia F.

description:
This was an awesome experience with entertainment as well as the drinks

We got the Thursday night showing since it's cheaper.  Probably less crowded too.  Not sure if it was really worth it to go to the earlier seating in the Casino.  You just have more time to gamble with fake money.  If we were to do it again, probably would want to get early seating in the Cabaret since it would seem like a show would be on at that point?

Loved how you could go from one room to the next and see storylines take place.  Repeat visits mean you would be seeing new stories if you follow different rooms.  Action is happening even as you go through different corridors and have peepshow access to stages set up as dressing rooms and private offices

Also loved how they would pull in audience members as part of the show. keeps you on your feet!

I was surprisingly delighted by how much i enjoyed the old-timey banter at the cabaret.  Cheesy jokes really made me laugh

finally, the drinks are expensive but well made -- would've been disappointed if a speakeasy didn't deliver on good drinks
author: Marshall Y.

description: Awesome expirence! Definitely getting your monies worth.
author: Jaimie L.

description:
This was one of the best experiences I've done in SF. I was initially skeptical about the Speakeasy SF - it seemed a bit expensive, I wasn't sure what to expect, getting dressed up felt awkward BUT from the moment I stepped inside I was completely blown away. I felt like I had traveled back in time! 

The decor was spot on, the performances were incredible and the drinks were top notch. It felt so realistic! 

Yes, it is a bit pricey but it is WELL worth it! If you've ever gone to a musical, ballet, concert or opera, then you should absolutely come here too. If you can let yourself go and have a little fun, you'll be pleasantly surprised!
author: TJ G.

description: It's a cool place. There were 8 in our group and all had a fantastic experience. The secret doors and secret passwords make it so exciting. I do like how they take your cellphones away. The show is not as entertaining- story line is good but slow. There are plenty of other rooms and things to do. We reserved for 2 booths initially but paid extra to keep only 1  for the whole night.. when we went to the back room they let other people sit in our booth. and when we showed our Rx to the host  they were able to "empty out another booth" for us; but my purse was on the original booth! We did find my purse- thankfully. The service was slightly inconsistent. Some wait staff gave us better service than others. Would NOT recommend PAYING EXTRA getting a booth for the night. The drinks in the back room are strong and yummy.
author: wendy c.

description: I celebrated my 30th birthday here with a group of about 20 people, and we had an amazing time. They were helpful in trying to coordinate times/tickets for my group and even did a ticket hold so we could purchase together. The check-in process is smooth, and they are in character from the time you meet up at a predetermined spot (they tell you where the day before) to the time the party ends. The venue is large, and you have free rein of the place and can interact with characters all you want - just don't go in any rooms marked "private." I enjoyed following the characters from room to room to follow their storylines and watching the variety of acts in the cabaret. I'm looking for an excuse to dress up and go back!
author: Erin M.

description:
What a fun experience! My husband and I highly recommend this joint!
It was fun to dress up and to see what everyone else was wearing. The cast was excellent and made you feel like you were stepping back in time. It was a bit on the spendy side, but most likely no more than a Vegas show! I loved that they do not allow phones, no distractions there!
Loved it!!
author: Nadine F.

description:
Done this twice and loved every minute of it!  I highly recommend doing this! Was so fun to get dressed up and hang out in a nice space - you get to be entertained and also participate in this unique experience. Its fun to wander through the various areas (bar, casino, cabaret, dressing room, etc.) to witness the various stories that unfold.  So much better than just sitting and watching a show. But you can do that instead - the cabaret has a constantly changing show of entertainers (singing, dancing, comedy) of the period you could just choose to sit and watch the whole time, but you'd really be missing out by not exploring! Exciting to guess who is an actor and who is an audience member since you usually can't tell since everyone is in period dress (actually very easily found and relatively affordable on Amazon).

Tip - order a drink and casino chips before you get there (they'll give you an option to set up a tab in advance since no cash or cards are accepted during the event to keep with the period theme). You'll have fun using the chips at the gaming tables (roulette, black jack, and craps) but they don't have any value so just fun to have some to play with.

Do this! :-)
author: Rose B.

description: An absolutely fabulous time!!  From the secret location to the costumes and the acting it was all fantastic!  I'd write more about the scenery and scenarios but that would ruin the experience for you!  One thing I will say is that one should be sure to move through all of the spaces a few times just to be sure you follow the story.  Awesome experience!  I will definitely go again!
author: Kristin S.

description: Abosolutly fantastic!!!!! It was completely realistic and interactive. and we loved every moment from finding the man in the yellow hat to every one who kept in character throughout the rooms. We went to the Cabernet room first and my husband was Dick, a famous person that people kept asking autographs from. The lighting was a bit dark and I accidentally ordered desserts instead of a drink. I think the writing on the menu should've been bigger because of the lighting but the lightening was good for the atmosphere. I did finally order my first drink of the night as recommended by the patron next to me. It was really good. Moving onto the next room, the bar, they had their own show going on. It was wonderful to watch. The waitress recommended a drink that I absolutely loved. It was on the sweet side just how I like it. It gave me a really good buzz that lasted the rest of the night. The 3rd room was the Casino in which my husband had a great time gambling and our dealer was really funny. He even said he wished he could stay longer if he could. I wish we could've taken pics inside but understand why. We left the night very satisfied. In the morning I finally got the itinerary of what we spent and I thought that it was over priced. A 3 piece desert was nearly 10 dollars, 1 macaroon, a small pastry with filling, and a half finger of something else. The 2 drinks I ordered were both between 16-19 dollars for the size that look like it should be for sample tastings. Even the beer my husband ordered which was the cheap east item on our bill was still quite expensive cuz he's s cup looked like it could be a tasting sample. We definitely had a good time and glad we ate before arriving cuz we prolly would've spent more on their food. Should we come again, which we might. I'll remember to drink before hand then enjoy everything else.
author: Melody R.

description: Can't say enough how much I enjoyed transporting back to the 1920s. I don't get the chance to dress up unless it's Halloween. But being invited to attend a birthday party here it gave me a chance to doll up. The dress code is firm. You must dress up. No exception. With this rule, this added more a solid feeling of being part of the 1920s. I love the fact, not one of the women dresses or men suits who were there that night wore the same outfits. Everyone was dressed to the Ts and authentic (so fun). The people who are working there blends in with the guest and you are not sure if they are the guest or works there. There were a couple of times I was asking how they know the birthday boy (hahaha). Anyway, you do not need to bring any money since the time you order the tickets you can save your credit card information and the time you are there, they give you a label card with your name. It took me a while since I was having such fun at the gambling room but there are three other rooms to go to. I highly recommend this place if you are thinking of transporting back to the 1920s.
author: Kathy T.

description:
We were very fortunate to have been guests at a private function at the Speakeasy and we enjoyed the experience immensely.  The staff, servers, and managers were professional and friendly.  They made us feel immediately at ease and appreciated.

You enter the Speakeasy through a grandfather clock so you know what's on the other side is going to be a good time (pun intended). The venue is classy retro-chic-meets-steampunk.  

Our party started in the lovely main stage area with a highlight of the company's progress through the years. The presentations left everyone in a joyous mood, ready for a party.  We continued to a bar/dining room where excellently mixed cocktails were served very quickly -- we love it when the bartender flames the orange zest into the drinks. Tasty hors d'ouevres were spread out and enjoyed as the wonderful trio sang and played the piano and banjo for us!

The remainder of the night was spent in the gaming hall where we enjoyed playing Black Jack, Craps, and Roulette. Even though no real money changed hands, the feeling was just as exciting as a trip to an old, hidden casino.  Everyone was dressed up which only added to the vibe.

We thoroughly enjoyed ourselves and highly recommend the Speakeasy for a perfectly entertaining evening!
author: Albert Y.

description:
Absolute B-L-A-S-T. The entire experience - from receiving the tickets in my email to being there in costume taking it all in - it was incredible. Three hours of showtime and we hadn't had enough, we were legitimately sad when we had to leave. 

The show is very interactive and the talent is fabulous! The effort that went into replicating the era is commendable. Highly recommend to anyone looking for a fun and refreshing night out, or visiting the area.

We started in the bar, do that! The dressing room is where we spent most our time, it's the behind-the-scenes drama and it's quite entertaining.
author: Laiken W.

description:
I've been wanting to come here for as long as I've known of its existence.  Based on the description, the emails, the photos, it clearly had a Sleep No More vibe, which is probably one of the best shows of all time. 

Unfortunately, it did not live up to expectations. Not even close.  Came here on their Halloween weekend, which I know is a slightly different experience than their usual, but since they charged the same and decided to put it on, I should be able to judge it by the same standards.

The bad: The place is small.  Within 10 minutes we felt like we had seen every part of it.  After several more hours of wandering, we realized we were pretty much right.  Paying for experiences was both a hassle and consistently put us out of the 1920s feel.  When you have guys with clipboards asking to check your ticket at every door, it's hard to lose yourself in the moment.  When those guys give you inconsistent and contradictory instructions, it starts feeling like a bad Disneyland ride. 

My advice: Double the price of the event and make everything included.  Instead of paper tickets, give people a key or a keepsake as their way to get in and to get charged for drinks/food.  

Only ask for an entry key once, if you have a problem with people sneaking in, then beef up security at the door rather than asking patrons to keep re-showing their tickets.  

Have more actors with lines who interact and less who just stumble around and around the room without adding much.  Have a dress code, and enforce it. Too many people came looking like they were going hit up a Hollywood club. 

Don't charge $35 for a photograph.  Every single person in the room has a phone that can hold over fifty thousand photos. Don't encourage us to use our phones (and the annoying flash) by placing ridiculous prices on your house photographer.  

I think this place could be awesome and I would love a Sleep No More type experience on the West Coast.  But as-is, it's not worth the money or the hassle.
author: Denis S.

description: Absolutely incredible experience. Best thing I've seen in SF since I moved here. I highly recommend walking around the hallways and trying to follow characters to take in more of the story.
author: Alex R.

description:
I came here last night with a group of 3.  The overall experience was great and I would recommend it to anyone who wants to do something new and fun.  I am always looking to try new things and go new places in the city. I found this place while searching a bit online.  After you buy the tickets they email you a "secret location" to meet and try in several ways to keep it as authentic as possible to the 1920's era while still having fun and giving them reasons to charge you $$$.

Pros:
There are three main rooms to explore and 3 smaller ones. Each room has its own "show" going on and you are free to come and go as you please.

Cocktail attire and or 1920s attire is required but 98% of the people there were in 1920s and really got into the process.

It was an overall good time and a step away from a normal night out. It was a semi unique experience and the shows were entertaining.

Cons:
We started in the casino where they took our coats and gave us the house rules.  Besides the rules we were not given much information on how to best experience the evening. Since you are free to come and go and the shows are all going on at once we were not really sure if the story was rotating or if the same story went from start to finish in each room.  As we moved about we always had a bit of fomo either of our story not being over or what we may be missing in the next. As I got to some places it seemed that the stories may have been connected but I still do not know if we stayed in the right places for the right amount of time if we would have seen an entire show sequentially the way they meant for us to see it.

Price: the show prices range and the drinks do as well which you would expect but since they make you create a tab ahead of time by the end of the night you may not know exactly how much you are spending.  I don't mind paying for those but the things that bother me a bit are the $10 fee for casino chips (which seem like part of the showing since you are paying for the experience and you should play a little) and the $35 fee for the photo. 
Towards the end of the night after a few drinks and seeing most of the show we came across a line of people and of course we had to ask what for.  They said it was a photo and since you are not allowed to bring phones inside we thought why not. Little did we know after a 15 minute line commitment we were waiting for a $35 black and white 5x7 (only 1 pic for 3 girls). 

All in all I would recommend but I do not feel the need to go back unless another group of friends really wanted to check it out. I would suggest dressing up and making the most of it.
author: Danielle B.

description: Brilliant interactive 1920's Speakeasy theater.  Most fun I've had in ages.  The performance is not just on the stage - The actors and actresses pop up time to time in the audience and settings, and weave their stories into the proceedings.  Drunken bar flys, boozy dames, struggling chorus girls, down on their luck workers...    Definitely dress up in 20's style if you go. I'm kind of a hum bug with that, but I did, and so glad.  It made the whole experience so much better...
author: Bradd H.

description:
The SpeakEasy, a really different kind of theater experience. The setting is so cool. Because it is a kind of interactive theater, you are walking right into the roaring 20's. Additionally, you are asked to dress in theme, so you fit right in. Watching the stories right in front of you, beside you. that is great fun. Like many others, the dressing room was one of my favs.

My son was my date; how perfect to have a younger guide. Trying to catch all that was happening around us was a challenge but made the experience all the more fun.

Thank you SpeakEasy, you really know your craft; immersive theater at its best. They have taken care to create the whole existence and I, the audience, had a memorable experience. Yes, I loved it...!!!
author: Sandra T.

description: can't complain. I liked the exerience but few things can be considered to improve service delivery.
author: Meg C.

description:
Awesome Experience!!  North Beach now has two awesome shows between The Speakeasy and Beach Blanket Babylon.  Perfect for birthdays or friends in town.  Very interactive.  Loved it.

Warning:  You MUST get into the theme to enjoy the show!  Come dressed in 1920's clothes and pretend like you are living in that time.  It's interactive if you get into it.
author: Mike Z.

description:
The Speakeasy SF is one of the best things to do in San Francisco. It's such a wonderful experience - especially for date night. 

When I was there I saw tons of groups - there was a birthday and a bachelorette party - having a great time in the casino. 

Sometimes actors give you one-on-one experiences...we were even brought inside the boss's office and drank real booze! 

The show lasts about 3.5 hours and it's totally worth the time/price. 

Highly recommended!
author: Jason D.

description:
Such a awesome night!
Went there with a bigger group but the actors made sure that everybody gets their own unique experience.
I highly recommend to split up into the different rooms if you go as a group.
The actors are all giving their best to give you a unforgettable night.
Highly recommended!
author: Leonard S.

description: Amazing production! I have attended twice and each time is amazing the actors are so into it. And the decor is so accurate for the times everything is art deco even the small details in the restrooms down to the soap dispensers and hand towels. The drinks are very strong even for my more than experienced drinker boyfriend, the food is danty and cute but I word say grab a heavy early dinner before attending as the drinks are heavily poured, you will thank me later! 10/10 bring your partner or bring a family member that adores the 20's.
author: Arielle H.

description: I had the BEST time here and can not wait to come again!  Since each character has their own story lines, you could come several times and still not see everything there is to see.  It was also fun to see what everyone in the audience was wearing too.  I recommend it to anyone who visits SF and of course to anyone who lives here!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
It wasn't interactive, of which they repeated reminded us, despite requiring that we dress up.  However, the "script" which we were then required to pay attention to, had no real through line to the plot and the characters were not connected.  So, there were sets of characters who, I guess, you could be interested in and then follow around, but not allowed to interact with in any way.  But the "dialogue" didn't really give you a reason to be interested.  The facility was well done, the costumes and actors were mostly good, there were (expensive) drinks and gambling (with no winnings).   Either make it interactive, since we dressed up to be a part of the ambiance, or make the "scenes" and characters interesting enough to care about so we would want to pay attention.

All in all, a little confusing and not all that interesting. And certainly NOT worth the price.
author: Steve W.

description: This was one of the best events I've attended in SF.  I really don't know what took me so long.  I can't go too much in depth because I really don't want to spoil it.  Just a few things.. make sure to DRESS UP. You don't want to be the odd one out who isn't dressed up like the Roaring 20's.  Many people were dressed up down to the T so be prepared.  This isn't a place where you can socialize and have a few drinks with friends.  I did go with a group of 12.  It's doable and we all still had fun, but this is a speakeasy so make sure to behave and speak speakeasy.  The actors were WONDERFUL!!!!!  We had more than enough time to go in all the rooms.  Drinks were a tad bit overpriced, but they were definitely strong.  The décor was so detailed and stayed true to the era.  I'm so glad that I got to experience this and would HIGHLY recommend!!
author: KB B.

description:
Complete waste of money. Save your
money and go to a jazz bar where you'll get better entertainment and actually be able to talk. This was a disappointing and amateur production. Staff for the most part was very rude and lacked that "umph" which really makes an immersive theatre experience. Maybe for somebody who's never experienced immersive theatre, this would be cool at most, but for somebody such as myself who's passionate about immersive theatre, this was a MAJOR disappointment. The actors would at times interact with you but you're expected to stand there like a mute because we aren't so privileged enough to talk. Give me a break. There is clearly no passion behind this production and the lackluster, straight up stupid performance attests to this. We were made to feel like hecklers if we tried to interact or respond to any actors. There isn't any direction in the entire production or clarity in what role we were allowed to play in this complete jumblef*ck of a performance. The only positive of the night was one of the actresses named Dorothy/ Dot who was a total star, she should be running the creative direction of the entire show.  
The jokes in the cabaret were stupid and struggled to crack a smile from anyone in the crowd. As we were not familiar with casino games, this room was entirely pointless for us. As we were trying to collect our phones from the phone check, somebody passed out and the security literally shoved us out of the way, extremely rudely and unexpectedly. I experienced rude actors throughout every stage of the experience, and not in a fun/ interesting way. Moral of the story: if the speakeasy wants to be respected, they better get their act together, do their research, give the actors some improv classes and completely restructure the current performance. There are too many high level immersive theatre experiences in the world that are cheaper and life changing, this simply doesn't cut it. Left me with a sour taste.
author: Eve M.

description:
It was really fun! Your experience started ones you get to the spot (check email, they will tell you).  
Actors did an amazing job - really hard to tell who is an actor! Everyone is dressed up so make sure you wear something nice and "in 20th". Cocktails are strong and really good! 
Probably not the best place to meet old friends and talk - at the very last room "security" lady came several times and told us "to speak easy". I guess we were too loud or it might be part of the acting. 
Definitely a great experience, they kicked everyone out around 11pm telling us "police" is coming and we have to run not to get caught.
Our group took a picture but I didn't find out how to get it yet.
author: Katerina S.

description: Celebrated my birthday in 1920s style at the Speakeasy SF. It was fun to start in the Cabaret to see the sit down stage performance. My friends and I all had fun exploring the different rooms and seeing all of the performances pop up around us. Next time we probably wouldn't order chips for the casino, because we spent so much time at the casino tables instead of continuing our explorations. I really enjoyed this unique, immersive experience especially since I love dressing up and getting into character.
author: Anna R.

description:
This experience allowed me to step back in time to an era that has always fascinated me--- 1920's Prohibition. I came prepared to pretend  by dressing in period costume. Most patrons did likewise. As I scanned the caberet, the bar and the casino I detected no distracting Steve Job's inspired garb snuffing out the historical illusion. Thank God for the dress code!
     The authentic setting was intriguing. The multi faceted entertainment was superb. The stout drinks were period inspired. I won't spoil the evening's details for those who have not yet had this amazing night's adventure--- which I highly recommend and will definetly repeat!
author: Susan R.

description: I attended with 5 others.  5 of us, including me, were very disappointed.  While the idea is great, there was no story of any interest in any of the rooms we visited.  The actors were all putting forth a valiant effort and I'm sure were doing their best with the material they had to work with.  But we left early and I, for one, felt this was a waste of time and money.
author: Jeff L.

description:
A friend of mine brought me to The Speakeasy for my birthday and my mind was blown! It was so much fun dressing up and meeting my party for dinner. When we walked down the street to find our clandestine contact, people stopped us and asked where we were going. Soon, we saw other groups dressed in 20s wear going in all different directions -- turns out there are four discreet entrances. 

The whole experience of being checked in and escorted into the "clock shop" was so much fun. Everyone turns off the technological doohickeys so there's breaking the illusion once you're in there. I was so happy to see that EVERYONE dresses up and some people really go out. After climbing through a grandfather clock, we entered the Speakeasy. Immediately, you are immersed in this world of intrigue. The drama is happening all around you! 

I don't want to say too much because it's amazing and you need to experience it for yourself. Suffice it to say that I had a friend in from out of town the next weekend and I knew I had to take her there! I managed to get tickets -- they do sell out and they stop selling them on the site 24 hours in advance (so you have to email and wait for them to call you back). It is a bit expensive -- $115 including fees -- and doesn't include drinks. If you buy chips, you don't win money but the gambling is fun and puts you front and center of the drama. You don't have to drink either though the drinks are fairly reasonable. 

Anyway, plan to eat in advance -- they just have a few snacks available to order, be there for three hours (trust me, you won't want to leave!), and be relieved of your phone addiction for a few blissful hours. It's like being in a movie and is such a wonderful escape from modern life.
author: Angelique L.

description:
this place is magic.

beyond being transported to a different place and time, you'll be immersed in dozens upon dozens of unique distinct characters and story arcs and dramatic moments developing all around you in every corner of the environment in every moment. there is more story to see here than you'd be able to absorb in several repeat visits. even beyond dramatic dialogue, you may witness a character's dream sequence, flashback memory, or drunken delusion. you can spy in on secret backstage fights, breakdowns, or moments of intimacy through secret two-way mirrors.
author: Garrett T.

description:
I don't know where to start! This event is the largest production I have ever been lucky enough to experience. It doesn't matter if you are on a first date, rekindling the romance in a stale relationship, celebrating an event, or just going out with friends, this is a Five-Star all-around experience. 
Deciding what ticket to buy and following the instructions for payment and getting there can be a little confusing - but you will be incredibly pleased with how your efforts pay off. So just suck it up. 
SF Speakeasy is pioneering a new form of submersible entertainment. Get on board now with the original. You'll be happy you did.
author: Kelly D.

description: I have now been to Speakeasy SF three times, at two different locations, and each trip has been more magical than the last. I don't want to give anything away, but suffice it to say every person I've ever brought to this has been moved and inspired by the amazing performances, storylines, singing talent, and production of this immersive show. The cocktails are delicious and pack a punch. The costumes are gorgeous. The show, in a lot of ways, feels like the soul of San Francisco. I can't recommend this experience highly enough--and aren't you due for a "watch repair"? ;)
author: Risa P.

description: Fantastic idea. Me and my girlfriends really felt teleported to the 1920's. Hours fly and you don't even notice. People (most) were dressed appropriately for that decade and actors were excellent. I recommend not sitting for too long in the same room, but follow at least a couple characters that you are interested in and put their stories together. This is the third time I go and still think I haven't seen everything. Go there, enjoy a drink and live the experience (very unique in San Francisco). Eat before. Food is awful. You're there to enjoy the experience too so no point in wasting your time eating for a long time in the same room! Thank you for another brilliant night.
author: Lety C.

description: As a producer, director and actor with my own theater troupe for over 20 years, I found the Speakeasy experience totally unique and highly entertaining as one of the best immersive productions I've ever been part of...believable to the last detail with great storylines, impressive casting...what more could you want if seeking a taste of 1) old S.F. and 2) prohibition era speakeasy life are your goals?  I hardly drank at all and still enjoyed it immensely.  Be sure to spend time ahead to prepare as authentic a Roaring Twenties costume as possible...you'll be glad you did.  And roam widely to fully sample all the 'wares' available.  Not to spoil but the ending is totally natural and in keeping with the night's theme!
author: Gary H.

description:
The Speakeasy is by far the best theatrical show in San Francisco. Imagine a place where you walk down a flight of stairs and step right into 1923. The Speakeasy takes you there and keeps you in that setting for the entirety of the show (about 3 hours). Remember, this isn't just a bar, this is an immersive theatrical experience. You're inside the show and you can watch it go on around you. You can explore the bar, the casino, and the cabaret at your own pace and there's always something going on. There's a lot of other special hidden locations to discover as well. Through the course of the night you'll find a story playing out with every one of the 30+ characters weaving their way in and out of it. It can be funny, sad, and completely terrifying at times. You can easily go 10 times and not see the same show twice.

A few tips: Dress nice. They're serious about people showing up in jeans being told they can't enter. The drinks are strong. Don't be the drunk jerk who disrupts the show and gets escorted out. Think about eating beforehand. They have snacks, but you're all dressed up and out on the town! Grab dinner. Don't expect to take a bunch of selfies inside. The no cellphones rule is strictly enforced. Explore. There's hidden rooms and things go on in every nook and cranny. There's even a few scenes that take place in the bathrooms!

This is the type of place that you're probably going to want to come back to since there's just too much to see in one or even three shows. I can't recommend it enough!
author: Sam E.

description:
One of the joys of partaking in something surprisingly special and unique is to have the experience unfold, revealing the unexpected.  Were I to say too much about The Speakeasy, it would only serve to lessen the experience for you.  In that regard, and counter to every other thing that gets written up on yelp I'd suggest you refer to the SF Chronicle's top-rated Speakeasy review (of 12/23/16) as well as the overall rating that yelpers have assigned to the experience (almost 5 stars, based on upwards of 130 reviews).  Based on this and this only, stop reading and decide if it's for you.  It's no fun to experience a surprise when you've already read all about it.  

Are you going?  Okay then, this is for you (no spoilers, promise):

*  The Speakeasy will run you about $85 per ticket though discount tickets can sometimes be obtained on the Today Tix app.  Add-ins can run the cost up even higher.  I purchased better seats for the cabaret (unnecessary) which added $10 per person to the ticket cost.  

*  The illicit bar/crooked casino/immersive theatrical experience runs a full 3 hours.  When purchasing your ticket you'll choose a starting location (I chose the bar, naturally).  You might also choose your second location.  After that, all bets are off.  There are at least 4 distinct areas to experience as many times as desired, always with something new and different going on.  There's also things to experience in the hallways and behind several hidden doorways.  So move around, follow people, and observe keenly for the best experience.

*  I enjoyed sitting in the bar and the cabaret, just watching the activity.  Another option is to move around more, following a character from one space to the next, so that you can better understand their "story".  If you don't follow a character from the onset, it will likely be difficult to understand their story arc.  

*  The theme here is Speakeasy so break out the appropriate garb.  This is not the place for your bodycon dress.  Instead, think flapper attire and maybe stop nearby, for a cocktail before the show; it's fun to see everyone in the local bars, pre-show, all decked out for a bygone era. 

*  Your credit card is on file.  Once inside, no money changes hands.  The cocktails in the bar are good, and run about $13.  Nibbles can be had in the Cabaret for $8 and up.  All purchases will be tallied and a record of your total charges will be emailed to you the following day.

*  Your phone goes into a sealed bag where it must remain from time of entry 'til departure.  You'll live.

I wasn't over the top in love with The Speakeasy but I appreciated its uniqueness and execution, and was entertained by it and, in that regard, I can say that neither the Chronicle critic nor the yelp community is wrong.  The Speakeasy makes for a fun and different, immersive evening of theater.
author: Tracey A.

description: An original experience with some amazing talent. Great service throughout the night and so entertaining! An interactive broadway time portal transports you to a unforgettable experience! Dress up, drink up and get lost in the grandeur!
author: Rachel M.

description: Whether you're visiting town or you live here in the city and are looking for a great night out look no further than The Speakeasy. Spend the evening stepping back into the 1920s with great drinks, immersive theater and endless entertainment. Be sure to head to the cabaret to see Oliver and Jeffries for plenty of laughs. There are many different ways to view the action; one of my favorites was the dressing room!
author: Darian N.

description: Unbelievable experience unlike any other. This is such a unique event. If you enjoy the roaring 20s and the speakeasy atmosphere, this is a must attend. We had the times of our lives and can't wait to go again. The people are friendly, the drinks are outstanding, and the entertainment is incredible.
author: Cooper D.

description:
What a great, unique experience. Nowadays, the true sign of an "exclusive" event is when you have to give up your phone, so you know you're in for some cool shit. 

The Speakeasy is an immersive, detailed venue depicting a 1920s Speakeasy (illegal club serving alcohol during Prohibition). There's 3 main areas that you can move among and there's "scenes" happening in each of them throughout the show. MOVE AROUND!  You will have a much better time if you explore and follow characters IMO. 

There's multiple different "storylines" going on but no overarching  "main story" that I could tell.  It's mainly character development and interaction. 

Interactivity - Not super high simply because there's so many ppl in the audience BUT you get out what you put in. If you're game and you respond well or even take initiative with talking to cast members, then you can have some fun, unique "scenes". Make up your own character and interact with cast as if they are who they're portraying and you'll have a blast!
author: Philip E.

description: I loves The Speakeasy SF. Its a unique experience and great for a date night or special occasion. It's set up like a 1920's speakeasy but has many different rooms that you can explore. There is a casino, cabaret and saloon. We spent about 4 hours here just drinking great cocktails and enjoying the performances of the actors. We didn't realize how dressed up people would be but definitely get into character and take a step back in time. Highly recommend!
author: Carol Ann V.

description:
Great way to spend a birthday or a special night out with a group of your favorite flapper girls and gangsters.

Entertaining SpeakEasy with the shows moving from room to room as you follow the action or discover more new characters.

Dress up and go with the flow. Enjoy some classic cocktails in the bowels of San Francisco.
author: Susan K.

description: We were at the Speakeasy SF for my birthday, it was amazing night that all the guests were acting like they were in 1920's with costumes, dances, make ups. When you meet the guy that gives you the address information, your life changes into another period. The place location is not public, you will get some information at the night before the event. Do not be late! It important and start with the bar session while you reseve your ticket. while booking online do not forget to buy chios for casino and photo. Do not forget it is a 4 dimension theatre with drinks, there is no eating place or food menu. Take your drink and act like you are in 1920s. Drinks are so cool, we loved them. Inyour prescription it was written that you should drink whiskey but you do not need to drink whiskey it is a kind of joke. Drink whatever you want. We tried 'better red wine, bubble drink and champagne'. All are great and have high alcohol level. Do not go the event by car, use othet options then you can drink during the event, and before going there you need to have dinner there is no food inside. And it is forbidden to go inside with your phone, they will take your phone    at the entrance. Yes! Find your costume and live the period!
author: Hatice S.

description:
The Speakeasy is a unique experience. Self-described as an "immersive theater" says it all. Great attention to detail with dozens of performers recreate a 1923 San Francisco speakeasy where alcohol and gambling are offered in this hidden lounge. Don't let its subterranean location fool you - this is a classy gin-joint. I had expected this would be a lighter entertainment fare - wrong. Aside from the cabaret, little frivolity exists. From snitty showgirls to WWI veterans, we see into the souls of our grandparents' generation.

We found four major sections of the Speakeasy: we were directed at first to the bar ("escorted" ticket), then moved through the casino to the cabaret, then hung out in the parlor. A hidden door takes us into a secret room with a two-way mirror and speaker, allowing us to observe behind the scenes of a 1920s makeup/dressing room. Everywhere you wander, expect a show of some sort.  A place for photos is said to exist, but we never saw it.

Precise details are down to the tin-tile ceiling and vintage cocktails (Chris had a "Corpse Reviver" and I a "Vieux Carre"). Chris dressed to the "nines" with her flapper dress. This may or may not have been the reason she got a rare personal interaction with a performer. My guess is that over half of the guests did their best to costume up for the occasion. 

I highly recommend it. If you go with a group, agree to breakup into couples and venture off on your own. It was a long show, a tad over 3  1/2  hours - you get your money's worth. We parked at the North Beach Garage, 745 Vallejo St. (the competitor across the street has poor reviews and may not be open that late). The parking garage is but two blocks away from the secret location. I can envision us going again - not this year, but later on. 
      Wayne J.  Aug. 18, 2017
author: Wayne J.

description:
Fun night out for sure, but the show does need to be tweaked. The "scenes" in the Casino go on and on. You are supposed to stand there and watch while the "conversation" is going on.  The games stop and you can't really talk while the "show" is on. It drags on a bit. The cocktail waitress took forever with drinks, so it took a while for us to get in the mood. Instructions on how the night will proceed were also pretty poor. Towards the end of the night, there is a "fight" scene between a SCREAMING woman and some guy. WTF? Totally killed my buzz. You're there to have fun. That part should definitely be changed or better yet, eliminated. Management should consider scenes with tipsy flappers flirting with customers, not a fight between a couple.
Food was pretty mediocre. I know, it's not a restaurant, but the sandwiches were 90% bread. Staff was SUPER unfriendly. I don't think i saw a smile the whole night. Maybe it's part of the act, but i don't think so. 
Great idea, but needs some improvement.
author: Niloufar M.

description: Very good experience. Highly encourage to arrive early and enjoy the show.  Pay attention to details and just be part of it.
author: Jane W.

description:
Someone else wanted to go, and I reluctantly tagged along.

After 3+ hours of immersive theater and amazing creativity I was amazed and wanted to return to see some of what I'd missed.

To tell you the story would be impossible. Each area, each person, each interaction is happening simultaneously and you can't be everywhere at once - and you don't need to be. There's the amazing stuff happening in front of you, and the stuff you KNOW is happening in the other areas. But you can't leave where you are because you might miss something...

Strong recommendation. These folks have created a fantastic experience.

And Johnny told me I was pretty good at being Rudy Valentino. Thanks, bub.
author: Dan S.

description: This show was absolutely amazing. From the second I walked in I felt completely immersed  in the 1920s. This was hands down the coolest show I've ever seen/been a part of.
author: Aaron H.

description: Great acting but it's like you're trapped at a bad bar at 130am... way too much drama and depressed story line. By the end of the night I was exhausted feeling so depressed about the characters life story... I don't need to pay to see others depressing story there is enough in the world right now.... won't recommend and wont come back. Thank you for a very depressing anniversary celebration!?!
author: Theresa W.

description: Amazing night! I don't want to give away their secrets, but it was surprisingly delightful from the second I met the contact person outside! Dress up for all you've got, grab some friends, and have a blast!
author: Alex W.

description: They worked out my bad billing situation with a quick phone call.
author: Amy W.

description: Highly recommend going with a group of friends. Go with people willing to separate and wander for a bit to pick up different threads of the story. Stop somewhere afterward to discuss the experience. Fun night!
author: N J.

description:
My bf and I attended for our first time last Saturday. 

I recommend purchasing tickets ahead of time. I called the box office and got last minute tickets which caused a few problems but the staff were able to sort it out. 

We had general tickets for the casino and accidentally got admitted into the cabaret but we were escorted by a staff member to the casino after checking in at the cabaret. We were greeted by what turns out to be the actual club owner (after doing more research about the club). He helped us get in contact with the prop rental gal (I forget her name) to rent accessories for my bf (bow tie, suspenders, and hat) who was very helpful and friendly. 

After watching others gamble for a bit,  the show got under way. The casino has a few fun characters and we got pulled into their story (maybe they picked up on our mentioning it was our first time?). We wandered and caught a good bit of those characters by happy accident.

Next time I think I want to start in the bar. 

We didn't end up finding the secret area to watch the dressing room scenes until the end so we definitely need to watch in there earlier in the night.  

I think there are some other hidden areas we didn't find, but I can't find any hints in other reviews as to what secret areas to look for.  If you know please pm me :)
author: Caitlin A.

description: Beyond amazing! Get ready to be transported back in time. Come dressed to impress and enjoy EVERYTHING this place has to offer. Feel free to explore but remember to follow the rules. No cell phone no photos. This is authentic prohibition era awesomeness. Highly recommend.
author: Karla F.

description:
I knew this was going to be good because I know some of the people in it, but it exceeded my already high expectations. I would definitely go back because I'm sure I didn't even capture half of what was going on.

The level of detail in everything was superb, and I even felt like I learned something after witnessing what I'm sure were very well-researched stories. It wasn't just kitsch. This isn't your typical "Gatsby" or "1920s" party that throws some black and gold decorations up and plays some jazz mixed in with modern music. This is the real deal.
author: Katrina M.

description:
The Speakeasy SF hosted a private birthday tonight for a friend of ours and it was an amazing event.
We entered through a "clock shop" on Broadway/Columbus and we were immediately led downstairs. The stairs were lit with overhead construction lights.  An older gentleman met us at the bottom of the stairs and asked what we knew about the horse race.  This was of course a prompt for us to give him the password.
Once we did- we were literally asked to walk through a grandfather clock which led us to the main Speakeasy.  This is a LARGE venue beautifully restored with a bar, casino, and theater.
The bar offered live jazz music and strong, well crafted cocktails.  The casino offers roulette, craps and black jack.
The theater was my favorite part of the whole experience.  The cabaret show was amazing with live music and dancing girls.  (look at the posted pics of the establishment for a video I uploaded of the cabaret show)  Beautiful tables surround the stage and all of the staff couldn't have been any more professional.  It's hard to explain peoples reactions when walking into the cabaret show--you are literally wowed.
It's a throwback to the 1920's and done very well.
There is a coat check for those that may need it.  The bathrooms are beautiful too.
Who knew that this place was here??
Clap! Clap! Clap!
author: Thomas D.

description: This was probably the best experience of my life. From start to ending - it was perfect. Can't think of something else so amazing or original. Big thanks to everyone who made this possible. I will definitely be coming back. I wish I could go there every day.
author: Oleg S.

description: Went there last weekend. Really fun and different to do. Loved the whole idea. Actors were excellent. I would just wear lots of warm clothes. It was cold is my only complaint. You have to go to see
author: Linda K.

description: Definitely something to experience at least once! We hope to attend again soon. And yes do be sure to dress up it's more fun for all around you.
author: Juanita F.

description:
Definitely one of the coolest experiences I've had, especially since I've never been to an immersive play before! We started out in the cabaret after meeting our mystery gal and getting the secret instructions to the venue, and had a great time.

The actors are all so talented and really make you feel like you're at a 1920s Speakeasy. There are three large rooms (the bar, the casino, and the cabaret) and many smaller rooms to observe (manager's office, dressing room, parlor, lots of hallways/stairwells). Of all the rooms, I best liked the cabaret--it's definitely the most entertaining of all the rooms, and the comic actors, musicians, and dancers make for a great show. Everyone makes an effort to dress appropriately for the period (although if you don't have flapper garb, a normal cocktail attire is fine too) which makes the experience even more fun.

However, the price of the ticket at $75 didn't really pay off--the play, while entertaining, was hard to follow and didn't provide a lot of intrigue or plot that made you want to stay until the very end. There's a few "plotlines" (read: characters that you can follow) but nothing really went anywhere or culminated in anything. It's definitely more of a place to just sit back and observe and slowly learn "secrets" through eavesdropping than an actual narrative.

The drinks were something terrible--even a basic gin and tonic or moscow mule tasted flavorless and bad. I didn't like their specialty cocktails either. The bubbly cocktail just tasted like tart champagne, and the velvet sea was strangely watery (although it's their most popular). You also have to be careful that others aren't accidentally included on your tab (you don't get the bill until a few days after). Definitely eat before you come, and definitely don't bother with the overpriced snacks. Tea sandwiches I think are only available in the Cabaret. But since people don't come here for the food (obviously), this shouldn't impact your opinion too much.

Tips:
- There are secret rooms (a closet, for example) that you can go into but only if invited. 
- Try to see if you can get a "mission" from a cast member. We were given the task of delivering a lost cuff link to "Tom" which was pretty fun, since we got to interact with the actors.
- Explore all the rooms! Some of the most interesting ones are the dressing room and parlor--sometimes even the hallways and staircases will have scenes.
- Skip the drinks and snacks.
author: Wendy W.

description: Best show ever! Unique!  A must!!! You feel like back in the days. I was against this dress code and embarrassed at first, but when you go with the flow it's actually really nice!
author: Shir D.

description:
What an amazing experience! It works best in a group setting, because you can all meet up afterwards and try to piece the various storylines together based on what each person saw. I wouldn't fault anyone for just going back multiple times and catching the different rooms and characters at different times, though; there's enough nuance, detail, and "ohhh!" moments to last many repeat viewings.

Overall an amazing, one-of-a-kind, and unforgettable experience. It should be on everyone's San Francisco Bucket List. (Pro-tip: bring friends from out of town to make them jealous that they can only see it once! :D)
author: Mark F.

description: This is one magical, unforgettable night out! The actors are plentiful and skilled, the storylines diverse and overlapping. The physical building itself is lavishly decorated and there is a divine, elegant sense of whimsy. The musicians, comedians, dancers, and singers are well trained and wonderfully personable. I have gone three times myself, and each time has been magical and glorious. From meeting at agreed upon locations for tickets, to entering through a clock or a clothesline, to wandering about in a moment from a distant past, the entire thing feels deliciously forbidden. If you possibly can, I recommend staying until the end, then returning to modern San Francisco in your 20s finery.
author: Caity M.

description:
tldr; awesome experience, super immersive theater, would recommend snagging a seat in the caberet and staying there for the night

Awesome, awesome experience. I've heard about the Speakeasy for awhile, and bought tickets for their show back in June. The SO and I went on a night in October and couldn't have been more impressed by what the team here is able to pull off.

The check in process is a little inefficient like some have mentioned, but I didn't mind it too much. We basically got checked in by an actress and from the minute we met her, it felt like we were being transported back in time. No phones are allowed, which also really helps maintain an appropriate atmosphere that feels realistic. After walking through a secret entrance which gave us speakeasy feels, we started off in the casino. This part I think is a little silly -- you have to pay for chips, even though you can't cash the chips in. We mistakenly bought enough chips for two to play, when we should have just bought one set since you're basically betting in intervals of 5 cents. The point of the experience really isn't to gamble all night. We spent some time in the casino and then once we noticed people flowing in between rooms, we started to move.

In general I don't want to give away too much about the storyline, but there are definitely multiple ways to handle this. You can either follow a character as they move around different rooms and follow one story line, or you can also stay in a room and just see snippets of storylines. The place is actually quite small, so within a few minutes of wandering, we managed to figure out where everything was. 

We ended up spending out most of our time in the caberet room. I loved that room. The shows were super engaging and funny, and there are some really meaningful storylines that I thought really hit home. The entertainment was just prime. Honestly, we would have been happy to just stay in that room all night. 

Some people have criticized that the story line gets too dark... I dunno. Sure some of the things may have been on the darker side, but honestly, I appreciated how real it felt. Sometimes life isn't all shiny, and I found the stories to be really interesting and engaging.

All in all, an expensive, though awesome way to spend a night. Really wonderful acting, the costume game is on point, and a cool way to feel like you've gotten transported back in time for a night.
author: Jasmine X.

description: My husband planned this event as we were celebrating our 3rd wedding anniversary, traveling from San Diego!  We took the suggestion of visiting "Decades of Fashion" and found the genuine deal of clothing attire!  Dressed like the women and men of the 20s, was just the start!  Not going to give up all the details you will experience with this event, just know it's theatrical and the experience...is LIVING the moment!  I felt like I jumped into a time-machine and experienced the era of time when prohibition was knocking on the door!  Oh, I have to HINT to the door upon door of events you will walk into...OK enough said...!
author: Carrie J.

description: If you've ever wished you could have a Midnight in Paris experience now you can! I want to go back every weekend and get lost in the amazing 1920'a world they've created. I'm also impressed with their quick and professional customer service. My husband was unable to attend last minute and I was worried I wouldn't get money back for his ticket. A quick email to customer service has taken care of a future ticket credit. Can't wait to return.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
You'll have a great time at The Speakeasy; it's definitely worth going to at least once. I went with my husband, and we had fun prowling around, but I noticed the big groups seemed to have an especially raucous evening, so I would recommend it if you have guests from out of town, or want to do something special for a birthday. It is kind of pricey, but I think you get a lot for your money, as the show runs pretty long, and you can visit different rooms. (Hint: keep moving around, because things are going on everywhere.) There are loads of performers and acts to watch. Be aware that the authors put a little undercurrent of darkness into the show; it's not all fringed dresses and drinking. Cheapster tip: you can get some non-alcoholic stuff that annoyingly is not listed on the menu. I got really thirsty for something non-dehydrating, so I asked for soda water, and they happily brought it in a big beer mug, and it was only $4.72 including the service charge; a lot cheaper than the cocktails. 

I do get the impression the show is purposely designed to get repeat customers by not revealing everything on a first visit. It's hard to see everything; we found out later that there were whole storylines going on that we missed, and we never found out the fates of some of the characters, so that was a little unsatisfying. But I can't fault the organizers for wanting to keep the business going whatever way they can; it's tough to do professional theater in San Francisco. I'm taking one star off for a few things I didn't like, such as anachronisms (I can't quite figure out why they specifically set the show in 1923 when they clearly wanted to use styles and events from later in the decade, and they also threw in a few things from beyond the 20's), but most people will find the show creates a satisfying world that's fun to visit.
author: Christine U.

description: You pay for the experience. I love that it's mandatory to dress up and you have to place your phone in a brown bag. I truly felt like I stepped back in time. The drinks were good and had lots of variety. I would eat before because the food isn't up to SF's "norm" of excellence. The cast stayed in character 100% of the time so much so that patrons start developing their own stories too.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
Went last night for my sister's birthday. Fun night overall but not worth the price to us, especially when you consider that you have to buy drinks, photos, and casino chips on top of that. 
It was an immersive event where the show was happening all around you but I was expecting a little more interaction with the characters. It was more like we were the furniture in their stage. 
Drinks took forever to come out, and our group ended up getting split up for a lot of it. 
The picture we paid for didn't really come out well and they would interrupt card games for "special" games with just the actors. This was totally a way to shuffle the cards but it was crummy because it took time away from playing. 
Also for the show at the end of the evening, the waitress came by with a cart of limoncello. We had reserved a special table, and she made it seem complimentary. She also didn't count right so we were charged for 5 when we only had 4. The drink itself was overly sweet and tiny, not worth the price. 
As I said, it was fun, but I was left feeling that I over-payed. Unique experience, but not quite enough for my taste.
author: Sarah S.

description: My husband surprised me with this (as best as he could, since I had to get a costume and get dressed up) for my 50th Birthday.  It was OUTSTANDING!    Every single detail is authentic and detailed.  They didn't miss a beat.  Lots of actors there, some interact with you, some you just watch.   They had a cabaret, a casino, a bar, lots of vignettes that you walk into and see actors playing out a scene.  There are 2 way mirrors into the ladies dressing rooms where you see and hear what's happening behind the scenes.   You can even witness gangsters making deals.  You set up a tab beforehand, so whenever you order something, whether it's chips for the casino, drinks or food, or go to the photobooth, you just show you "prescription for alcohol" and it goes onto your tab.  We had dinner ahead of time in North Beach, then met our secret person, who aimed us toward their secret entrance down an alley way.  There is a big white grand piano and big band playing in the cabaret.  EVERYONE Is in costume.   It's AWESOME!   It was the best birthday I've ever had.  We will be going back, it was so great.  Very fun.  We were there for about 4 hours, and there is so much to see and do, the time flew by.   Highly recommend!   If you ever get the chance, do it!
author: Lori B.

description:
Truly an outstanding experience. I felt as though I was transported back to the roaring 1920s for the evening. The actors were fantastic and the dialogue and topics they discussed felt realistic and were often hilarious. It is well worth the effort to dress the part, as it will help you suspend disbelief and immerse yourself in your environment.

I will definitely return. Kudos to everyone at the Speakeasy for creating a memorable experience.
author: Mick C.

description:
WOW! What a magical night! The Speakeasy went above and beyond expectations, the actors were brilliant and the detail was impressive. No matter what, everyone will have a unique experience as the immersive play surrounds you and can shift and change depending on what room you're in. It's fun following the story line and comparing notes with your friends at the end. 

Quick tips:
- book the cabaret as your first stop.

- you don't need to book a table for the whole night, it's not necessary, just do it for the first scene. You can always go back and sit at a non-reserved table.

- definitely get a casino chip. The casino was a lot of fun! 

- dressing in period is a must!! Everyone goes all out so it's hard to tell who's an actor and who's a spectator. 

- if you're doing an early show get a late lunch or a quick bite to eat beforehand.

- book book book!! You won't regret it!
author: Hannah W.

description:
Holy cow what an experience!!!! Do do do get whatever ticket you can find and go. You'll want to go again and follow other characters thru the night. It's incredibly well produced and unlike anything in the emersive theater realm that I've ever experienced.

Highly recommended

Strong drinks (buy at least three and see if you can keep up), incredible performances, superb production all around. Go. Do this. Take friends. Explore any door or panel that doesn't say private.

Be quite and just experience....even in the freakin bathroom!!!! Everything is fair game and you'll truly start to feel like you have stepped into the prohibition era. Man. I'm floored. It was awesome. Join us the next time we go; we'd love to introduce you to something super cool!
author: Todd H.

description:
All other reviewers were spot on about the details of this experience although it definitely was not the night of my life. It was entertaining and something to experience, but I'm not sure I would ever do it again. I did appreciate how organized and seamless the night seemed. Do not buy extra seats for the cabaret as you can sit there anytime you want. Our drinks were super strong (14 each). We started in the casino which was pretty cool. Don't buy too many chips as you may not have enough time to use them. Definitely dress up. That's part of the whole experience. Do a little bit of research to find out what people wore in the 20s if you don't know. It says cocktail attire but it really is better if you dress in 20s style. 

I don't know. I could take it or leave it. It was like meh to me.
author: Mindy T.

description:
Find and unique evening! I highly recommend that you start in the cabaret - and then enjoy the drama as you wander the theater space. 
Some of the acting is truly fabulous - and everyone stayed in character at all times.
It was fun and different - and I recommend it!
author: Nina L.

description: Worth every penny. I was impressed by the quality of the actors, singing, dancing, etc. It's so unique you'll forget the bill instantly. Highly recommended.
author: Alexis R.

description: So much fun! I know it's a little pricey, but when can you get all dressed up and be entertained in so many ways? I went twice and both times were different and fun. Guys, if you haven't taken your lady yet, it's a perfect date night.
author: Humuhumunukunukuapua'a F.

description:
The other reviews that mention earlier entry or preferred seating as being unimportant are correct.  Do what you can to buy discounted tickets to Speakeasy if you decide to go, it is not worth the full price.  While the production value of the party is high, the experiential value of it is not.  
Suggestions: either make the casino chips worth something like discounts on drinks or make them easier to win by using mechanical dice so everyone gets more excited.  The constant interruption of the performances in the casino were distracting and got stale very quickly.  Instead, think about intermixing them into the party, like having the pit boss come around and talk with real people, same with the other actors! The other rooms were also just a lot of sitting around, find ways to involve the audience more or let them move about freely.
author: Kate T.

description:
The Speakeasy SF is a great immersive theater experience with three areas: a bar (alcohol), cabaret show, and casino. I went with a group of 7 for a bachelor and bachelorette party, and we had a unique and memorable experience. Tickets are prepurchased. One day before the event, you'll get an email with the location and instructions to gain access to the exclusive 1920's club. Dress code requires appropriate vintage wear. No t-shirts, sneakers, or jeans. There is also no cell phone access once you go inside. Minus 1 star for lack of flexibility. In light of the theater portion in all 3 areas, you're really prevented from enjoying the casino or the bar experience.
TIPS.
 - Look for discount tickets @ TodayTix app or website.
 - Take group photos earlier in the night as they take time to print. Photo booth may be found by the casino. 
 - Start at the bar if you can. It's a great way to get introduced in the beginning. Once that's done, you can determine your own schedule at the cabaret and casino.
author: Tina C.

description:
Some friends and I went to this amazing immersive theater experience.  What a fun time! 

Part of the fun is not knowing too much so I'll keep details quiet but here's one piece of advice ... looking for hidden rooms.
author: Jason H.

description: Last night was our third time at the Speakeasy. Every time a different experience, a different storyline, a different discovery. It's nearly impossible to believe that this magical place exists beneath the pavement of old San Francisco. Come, shut off your phone and turn on the good times. The talent here is over the top. I'm excited to see what they do next year!
author: Marisa L.

description:
My friends and I went for a friend's birthday and had a wonderful time! It was a unique and fun experience! We loved the way everyone stayed in character! Reading the reviews on Yelp are very helpful if you want to know what to expect and what to do and what not to do!
I do want to point out to make sure you take a hand bag big enough to stash your cell phone since it has to be put into a manilla type envelope (I had a small flapper purse). I did end loosing my brand new phone inside but FORTUNATELY the staff found it and returned it to me! I was so appreciative of their honesty!
author: mary T.

description:
Absolutely lovely experience. I went for the second time and brought family members.

However, one recommendation I have for the production is: Can we be a little more diverse with the casting? I counted no minorities during my first visit, and only 2 the second time. 

Speakeasies in the 20s were places where white and black actually mixed, so there should be no excuse for the current lack of inclusion (not to mention adding other minorities in the year 2017). I only have good things to say about THE SPEAKEASY otherwise, but I do hope to see some social change!
author: Fin D.

description:
I've seen 2 immersive plays - one in London and one in NYC, both produced by Punchdrunk Theatre Company. The Speakeasy SF has cool ideas and decor was pretty decent for 20s. But the whole show was executed poorly. It was hard to hear the cast speak, because everyone else wasn't speaking easy (and bear in mind that it's a speakeasy). The audience wasn't engaged, and the plot was boring. Honestly, I had more fun at the casino than actually paying attention to the storyline. Cabaret show was very meh, comparing to this local cabaret show by TRIBE (and it was only $15/person!). Overall, this show needs more work done. 

Lastly, if you've never watched an immersive show and just don't watch musicals/plays that often, this could be a great start for you. If not, forget it. Don't waste your $100+.
author: Jenny W.

description: Went to Speakeasy for the first time last Sunday and had so much fun. It's such a unique experience. My friends and I really felt transported to a San Francisco in 1923.  The acting and singing are first rate and the setting is amazing. The attention to detail of all the rooms is spectacular. We started in the Cabernet, migrated to the casino and ended in the bar. Sometimes it was a little hard to follow the narrative but we were still able to get into the character stories.
