Our servers were attentive and pleasant, even with all the chaos of the show happening around them. I didn't want the night to end. I am already planning to go again. I hope it runs forever.
author: Tena L.

description:
My sister and cousin were in town so I wanted to take them both, was worried because my cousin is 16, but she barely made the age limit to get in which was amazing! We all got super dolled up and loved the theme. Overall I think that this is a show/event that you have to come to a dozen times because there is so much to see and do that you can't see everything in one night, but you can try. One of the cast members advised us to try to move rooms around every 10 minutes and to split up from each other and he had the right idea! Splitting up let us all see different things and at the end of the night we all huddled around and talked about what we saw when we were away with each other. I was astounded of the level of acting that went on throughout the night. It takes an amazing cast to keep up their characters for hours when you are in an interactive stage in multiple rooms, but this event did it well. 

I don't want to spoil much, because what is the fun in that, but I do think it would have helped to know a few things before buying your tickets. 
1. Choose your starting room carefully. That room will decided where you start your night. We started with the Cabernet and spent roughly 30-40 minutes there. Very burlesque overall in this room.
2. If you choose the Cabernet, you can choose the booths (which is very exclusive), but online you will need to pay I think ~$20 per person for the booth for the first hour. We had three people so it was $60 for the 1 hour. If the 20 is too much I would recommend getting a table for the Cab since it will most likely put you close to the stage.
3. WEAR A WATCH. In order to keep the event a hush hush, you aren't allowed to use your phone for the entire event. You have to turn your electronics off and put them in a brown bag before you even are allowed in. We didn't wear a watch and we had no idea what time it was the entire night until the end of the event. 
4. Keep in mind, the show doesn't stop or repeat. During the event my group thought that each room would have a "show" and we would be able to get to see them all. Totally wrong, as the night goes in the characters develop and we learn more about them. My recommendation is to find a character you like and follow them! It's fun and you get to see all about them. 
5. You need to set up your bar tab at least noon of the event. They don't do a cash/card bar at the event so you have to set up a tab beforehand if you want anything during the event. They had complimentary water next to the bar, but it is a long event and you might get thirsty for more than water. If you do want to try something, TRY THE VELVET SEA! Super sweet and yummy. I loved it! At the end of the night your tab goes directly on your card with an 18% tip and they email you the receipt.
6. Eat ahead of time. You are in SF, food is a plenty. I recommend eating in the area and walking to the event. If you are driving, the area gets difficult to find parking so make extra time to find parking. Most metered stop at 6 pm, well before the event starts.
author: Devika B.

description: I wanted to love this experience and it was fun but didn't live up to the hype, especially for the money. Pros: unique experience, the cabaret dancing girls were great, seeing how everyone got dressed up was fun, some of the theater parts were interesting/entertaining. Cons: so many people lined up in the alley waiting to talk to the girl in the red trench coat or whatever ... then in our case they screwed up our order and we had to wait for someone to go get the right carnations or something. That is to say it didn't go smoothly and feel authentic. The space is surprisingly smaller than expected. Not lots of 'nooks and crannies' to explore and too many people there to make it feel personal. Glad I went, definitely a fun unique night out but lacking in several ways.
author: Chandra R.

description:
I mean come on...

Who wouldn't want to dress up snazzy in 1920s attire, sip some stiff drinks, and enjoy a great show about the Prohibition? 

After dinner, a group of us walked up to an alleyway to meet our greeter in a yellow fedora and scarf. When some magic words had been exchanged, we were then escorted to the clock shop and asked to step foot into a grandfather clock. The rest...is for you to find out!

To sum it up, the show was amazing: immersive, dramatic, and informational about that time period. The decor and costume of the actors were stunning: from the cabaret theater to the poker room. I enjoyed how interactive it was and how you are free to roam around as you wish. You can play in the casino, grab a drink at the bar, or take a seat and enjoy the show, while performances are happening simultaneously. 

I absolutely loved it. It was fun dressing up and feeling as if you really are back in the 20s. The experience is one to remember. Sheer entertainment and will most likely come again to catch more acts.
author: Kimly N.

description: Had an amazing time last night. Immersing yourself into a blast to the past.
author: Marc M.

description: Wonderful experience. Came here for a friend's birthday not knowing what to expect. They do an AMAZING job making it really feel like you're back in the 20s, with plenty of talented actors in highly immersive storylines. They even respond in character if you ask them questions. Five stars. Never experienced anything quite like it.
author: Ricky L.

description: Really enjoyed the evening. The actors were amazing, always staying in character. I was not happy with how the evening started. I paid for premium tickets and I thought I was going to be seated early. When we got to the meeting place on a street corner we were there with 12 other groups. We had to wait for our contact to speak with many other people before we got instructions on where to go for the entrance. I would have much rather waited in a warm bar for the contact person. And, the speakeasy would make more money from drinks. Would have given 5 stars if I didn't have to wait in the cold for so long.
author: Jessica M.

description: How? How does this get 4.5 stars?  Acts are so bad and cheesy, drink I had was sweet and warm (and took FOREVER to get) and it was a claustrophobics NIGHTMARE.  One of our friends was "kid napped" from our group and he was in hell... some people on staff (actors) "passed him around" and asked him extremely inappropriate questions.  "What positions do you like?", "what did your last sex experiences bush smell like?"   Like, for real?   Place was absolute shit and a waste of money.  Few of the staff were so nice, that was the only light.  Overall horrid experience.
author: Jason D.

description: This is our second time attending, and this time, we hosted a corporate retreat for 20. Dori, the box office manager, was extremely helpful in planning our event and very responsive. We had a really great experience. Am continually amazed how they pull this off and really worth experiencing. The actors are great, the atmosphere is fun, lively and keeps you fully engaged. All that attended have plans to go again, since each time, you experience something new. In order to get the full experience, I highly recommend dressing in the '20's attire...makes for a festive and fun evening! It really us a magical night!
author: Heidi C.

description: Best Saturday night I've had in a long time.  Play along, go out of your way to engage with the actors and you'll see there's more to the show than what's immediately apparent.  Would love to go again and witness the story lines that I missed the first time around.
author: Ahren A.

description:
When you sign up for a visit, I'd recommend you select to start the experience at the Cabaret. Well before the visit, allow yourself time to find a cool period outfit to wear (the invite says cocktail attire, but you'll have more fun dressing for the era whether you're a guy or a gal), figure out where to be and when, and you'll  enjoy arriving to your secret entrance a lot more. Otherwise you'll be trying to go through your email/text to see who it was again you were supposed to meet and where, and what is it again that happens next.... etc. There's a lot in the details, and you won't have your phone once you get there anyway (you get to keep it, but it will be sealed in a pouch) and really you just won't want to ruin the fun by fiddling with any of that.

Other than that, the less you know in advance, the more fun you'll have. It's a bit pricey, but there are some deals available now and then, and even for the $$$, it really is quite a production.
author: Anja H.

description: I have been lucky enough to visit the Speakeasy almost half a dozen times in it's various incarnations around San Francisco over the past few years. It is a superlative interactive and theatrical extravaganza! I still don't think I have caught all the storylines and threads, even by coming in at different times and entrance choices. This night out is a fantastic reason to get gussied up dapper and flapper style, have dinner in North Beach, and drink great cocktails. Maybe one more than you should have, but just one more ;-) The space has been built out and the whole show designed impeccably. I am a connoisseur of great things to do in San Francisco, and The Speakeasy is high on my list. I already have plans to go back, and will do so every once in a while, for as long as I can. Hopefully I'll see you there!
author: Heather G.

description:
I absolutely loved this show. For sheer entertainment value, I would rank it higher than "Sleep No More." 

If you are someone who is interested in immersive and site-specific theater, if you listen to the No Proscenium podcast, if you have an inkling this might be the kind of show you'd enjoy: GO. Do not hesitate. You are guaranteed to have a good time.

If you're not sure if this is the kind of show for you, but you like a fun evening out, GO! You could spend the entire evening in the cabaret enjoying the 6 piece band, the dancing girls, and the unbelievably talented host's terrible puns, and you would have gotten more than your money's worth in entertainment. But if you are feeling adventurous, you can gamble in the casino, visit the bar, and sneak around looking for nooks and crannies to observe the action.

Can't say enough good things. So glad I went. Looking forward to going again and again!
author: Myles N.

description:
An evening at The Speakeasy SF, courtesy of discounted tickets won in a recent lottery, was an absolutely incredible and memorable event. I initially had plans to visit before their formal soft opening, but regrettably had to cancel due to an injury - glad I still made a point of visiting!

THE OVERVIEW.
+ Dress in theme; I don't care if it's a nuisance for you to change after work, or to dig up some old sequined number. It's really much more enjoyable if you put in the effort
~ It's not hard to find the initial entrance, just look for the gaggle of millennials in period costume swarming the street corner
+ The staff does a good job separating the large group and herding you into separate rooms (the event basically starts with people divided into 3 groups, but after some time, you're free to roam the halls)
+ The actors are quick on their toes, deliver a terrific performance, and very personable. At no point did I feel awkward or uncomfortable - it was a unique evening, for sure
+ The drinks are strong and cold, try at least a few
+ Make a point of spending a significant amount of time in each area (the bar, the cabaret, the casino) - there are many storylines that intertwine, and it's fun to follow along

PRO TIPS.
- Set up your bar tab in advance (by linking your credit card to your account when you purchase tickets online) - no cash or card can be used at The Speakeasy, only the wooden identifier chip you're given upon entering
- Don't bother buying a casino chip, unless you genuinely want to faux-gamble
- Don't bother paying to reserve seats at the cabaret; while it was nice that we had very close seats our first time in the little theater, they don't super police who sits where, and our seats were grabbed by opportunists the next few times we went in. There are plenty of non-paid seats, so save yourself the $$
- Don't fuss about having to turn off your phones, life is more valuable when you can actually live in the moment
- Be quiet (speak easy, folks)

It's not an inexpensive evening, but considering that the actors are basically "on" for 3-4 hours, non-stop, and you're being entertained non-stop, it's well worth the price of admission. I can't wait to go back once they've changed their scripts around a bit.
author: Claire S.

description: I was so impressed and enchanted with this amazing, physically beautiful production. It's a fun adventure, even starting on the streetcorners where you have to meet people to send you to the right location, because you already have a sense of complicity with random other people on the street who are dressed up in 20s garb just to see a show. You start picking out people dining in restaurants pre-show in their fringed dresses and cupid's bow lipstick. Once inside, the drinks are excellent and strong, and about 8 zillion story lines emerge and you can only follow so many-- I already can't wait to go back and make some other choices in what I follow. The set design is impeccable, the cast talented and sharp. When the big bustling rooms (the cabaret, the casino, the bar) get to be a bit much, you can find stories playing out in other much quieter places, sometimes one-on-one with an actor. My friend and I ended up in the ladies room reading erotica. I am usually kind of eye-rolly about having to dress up for theme nights, but I was really glad I did (and that so many others did.) (Even if you just made a nod towards the theme with cupid's bow lips and long beads over a shift dress, it would be great. Having so many audience members who really commit to it really keeps the whole environment fun.) Definitely check out the dressing room, the peepholes into the boss's office, and a bunch of places I'm sure I didn't even find on this first trip.
author: Victoria L.

description:
This is one of the most unique and magical experiences - theatrical or otherwise - that I've had anywhere. And as far as I'm concerned, it's worth every penny of the ticket price, hands down. 

I attended The Speakeasy once last year in previews and just experienced it again last night. I'm absolutely blown away at the detail and the array of talent that goes into this huge and multi-faceted production. It's an incredible space with multiple rooms where great attention to detail and design has clearly been given, being as true as possible to how these rooms (right down to the bathrooms!) would have looked in the 1920s. There are some fantastic actors, singers, dancers, musicians, and performers, and it blows me away how they can keep going despite the fact that, no doubt, every performance has its new challenges because the audience is so unpredictable. It can be a bit difficult to get a sense of a story line (mainly because it's so fun to just wander around and because it can be challenging to follow the characters when the place is so full of happy people milling about everywhere), but that really doesn't bother me because my favorite part is the very real feeling of being transported into another time and soaking up the feeling of being in the 1920s. It's magical, and when it was over I didn't want it to end, but I knew the actors (and crew/staff) must be exhausted -- we were in there for three and a half hours or so! 

If I can attempt to sum it up, I would say it's part "Chicago (the musical)," part Charlie Chaplin, part vaudeville, part "The Godfather," part "Bugsy Malone," part "Funny Girl," part Disneyland, part "Cabaret (the musical)," and 100% fun and magical, intriguing, and entertaining. The first time in, it'll knock your socks off (it sure did mine!). Second time, you have a better understanding of how it all works, and you can really start to sink your teeth in (and it likely will still knock your socks off!). I look forward to going again.

Great for tourists and visitors to the great city of SF (the story lines are geared towards what really was happening in SF in the 1920s), locals, theater goers, non-theater goers,  young and old alike. I highly recommend it and hope it will continue to run for a long, long time.
author: Peter B.

description:
A solid 4 star experience.  Why not 5 star?  Well, it's easy to criticize, so let's first focus on what was GREAT about it...  

This is a really cool concept, and it's apparent they've worked hard to create a convincing atmosphere so we patrons are transported back in time.  It's really pretty fascinating to enter into the property and breath it all in - the sets, the costumes, the music.  Most guests embraced the recommendation to wear period attire, and every single person respected the 'no cell phone' rule (how refreshing).  I liked that my bar tab was set-up in advance, and the cocktails offered are authentic.

My friends & I started in the bar and were immediately enthralled with the live show before us.  The actors are a talented bunch, for sure, and have worked hard to give life to their characters.  After some scenes, we were guided to the cabaret, which we also greatly enjoyed.  The vaudeville emcee is a genius of his craft.  We found the showgirls to be mesmerizing.  But my hands down favorite was Velma, sultry chanteuse extraordinaire.  The only thing I did not like about the cabaret was at one point there was an impromptu dance party which made absolutely no sense and should be eliminated from the show as soon as possible (Boxcar Productions, I beg you to please make note).

We visited the third room- the Casino, but found it unenjoyable for a few reasons.  Roulette, craps, & handling casino chips creates a louder atmosphere by its very nature, making it easy to forget we're supposed to stay quiet for acting scenes.  Also, we were having fun playing blackjack (hence, facing the dealer and not wanting to turn to observe the scene in the middle of the room).  We hadn't even realized we were speaking above a whisper when we were shushed by the staff (a couple times).  It made us frustrated there wasn't a designated room we could enjoy our own conversation & have some cocktails.  We really enjoyed the acting that night, but the truth is, after a couple hours we experienced attention fatigue.  We hope they will eventually give patrons a room to relax and I personally think this casino would be the ideal space.

This now brings me to the script.  It covers serious subject matter that weighed heavily on people's minds at that time.  The scenes we watched were filled with anguish, sadness, & conflict.  I felt my eyes wet with tears more than once.  I craved a break from the heaviness, and from reading other reviews here, it's clear other patrons feel the same.  I hope the writers will insert more lighthearted story lines.  There are a few scenes in which you may find yourself breaking a smile, but those moments are rare and also seemed to be based in characters' deep-rooted pain.  That said, I would like to reiterate again how talented the actors are.  I particularly enjoyed the soap salesman at the bar.  And Velma- Velma forever!

My Likes...
- This is a rare opportunity to experience a bygone era.  Great sets, great costumes, great actors, great music.  I ate it up.
- We went out for drinks in our costumes/outfits beforehand, and received a gazillion compliments from people who were fascinated with us.
- The story lines are all based in SF, and so there are references to the extended bay area.  We got a kick out of this.
- The cocktails offered are from the era, and the setting up your tab in advance allows an easy system to order drinks and be billed later.
- The staff was incredibly helpful.  When we needed their help, they guided us around and pointed out things we might have otherwise missed.

My Dislikes...
- The check-in process was lengthy, and having a couple of dozen patrons waiting outside in Gatsby-type attire inadvertently advertises the club's location.
- I spent $50 to purchase a cabaret table in advance.  As it turns out, the room had ample seating with half the chairs remaining empty.   
- I spent $60 to purchase casino chips in advance.  As it turns out, I could have purchased chips there and really needed only one or two ($10-20)
- I spent a week practicing my Charleston dance moves, and then the cabaret had a dance party featuring modern songs (huh???)
- The story lines are too dark, sometimes rather explosive.  There was no room offered to just relax and have a cocktail without a scene bursting in.

Why would someone give it a 1-star review?  That baffles me.  Even if this is not your cup of tea, I can't imagine why anyone would want to bash it.  I'm sorry they disliked it as much as they did.  As for me- I hope the production company makes some changes to the things I pointed out, but over all, I greatly enjoyed the experience and I definitely plan to go back.
author: Tutie T.

description: Thoroughly impressive experience. Felt like living in a dream. The acting was especially impressive - the actors payed attention to the smallest details. For example, I noticed one of the actors was visibly distressed, and you only find out why maybe 10 minutes later. Drinks were incredible and snack food was good. The people that went were all dressed in era appropriate attire. There's so much to see that I'd definitely go again, maybe a couple times.
author: Billy T.

description: This was the most memorable and fun things I've ever done with my friends. Scenes are being played around you, so go to room to room and enjoy the action. Separate from your friends and drink the velvet sea cocktail!
author: Mark A.

description:
I wanted to love the Speakeasy experience; I really did.  However, I have to say that I don't think I would recommend the show to others.  I went with my wife and another couple, all of us did a great job getting dressed for the period.  We had a great dinner prior to the show in North Beach and received many compliments on our attire.  This part of the evening was wonderful, and we enjoyed all of the reactions we got from tourists and locals alike.  

We arrived at the secret destination at our appointed time with many others who were excited to be attending the show.  We were told the rules (no talking/no electronics) and directed to our entry leading to the cocktail lounge. The performance started off well with some interesting dialogue between the bartenders and some of the "bar regulars(actors)".  However, the performance turned weirdly morbid.  I won't be a spoiler and detail the specifics, but the scene turned screamingly truly dark and weird.  One of my party told me later she saw an audience member in tears, not exactly what you anticipate going into a "Speakeasy". 

The casino likewise interjected really disjointed segments of screeching negativity. It was also odd trying to be patrons of a casino, but being told to whisper or not to talk. While the casino game operators would deal the cards/spin the wheel, they did not seem to be in the spirit of the Speakeasy.  Likewise, the ladies who handled the cocktails were not included in the "Speakeasy" spirit. It seems a shame, because I think the casino, if handled in a less scripted, more improv manner could be a real interesting kind of free form theater that truly integrated the audience into the scene. 

The cabaret was the most fun, particularly when they got the audience up and dancing, but this part of the show also seemed to be forced to weave in segments of depression to keep it from being a truly enjoyable experience.  

The Speakeasy's producer/director clearly have the right to stage whatever tone of show they choose to, but my group left very surprised by what a dark show it was. Clearly the actors and production staff have worked very hard.  However, I think when the audience comes, dressed in their Roaring 20's best, they are anticipating jazzy music, vaudeville, gangsters, debauchery, not a dark examination of the pain of war, PTSD, death of a son, child labor, women being abused, etc.  If the show had a different tone, I think my wife and I would be repeat patrons, but I don't think we will return, nor recommend it to others.
author: Blake M.

description: AMAZING!!! Completely exceeded my expectations. Super cool experience. I actually felt like I was in the 1920's. Dressing up is a must!
author: Samita S.

description: What a fun show! I can't wait to go back and have been highly recommending it to everyone! All the performers were amazing, approachable and very professional. They thought of every detail. So impressed!
author: Sofia K.

description:
A magical experience! We were swept up in the show and had a blast exploring the space.

There are some incredible "slice of life" moments, as well as more surreal musical-theater type scenes, all of which blend into an enjoyable whole. I was personally grabbed for a private scene that included the opportunity to dialogue with several of the characters (I'm not sure how they decide who to include, since my date was closer to the action, so to speak).

I wish we had gone with friends so we could compare notes on the different experiences available depending on where you choose to spend your time, or which characters you follow.
Based on this showing, I loved the performances of the lead singer and master of ceremonies (who we saw in several different areas) and I have to say that the cabaret band (especially the clarinetist!) was amazing.

There is clearly an incredible amount of planning and coordination involved in this show, it's like nothing I've seen before.

If you bring a sense of wonder and are ready for an immersive experience, you're sure to be delighted.
author: Joshua Z.

description:
This is my first really bad Yelp review.  Unfortunately, this "new and improved" air conditioned Speakeasy is not very fun at all.  SO many rules and regulations, you can't really move about freely unless you get late entry, you can't gamble or order a drink if one of the actors is about to do a poorly written "scene", you can't speak to each other without being shushed.  I understand it's a Speakeasy, but please.  The actors are taking themselves way too seriously for an amateur show.  Yes, you are paying over a hundred dollars each (with tokens and a reserved seat which you don't need) to watch amateurs.

Best part of the night was when the waitress told me if I moved she would give my drink to someone else and still charge me anyway.  I never planned on moving because I really wanted to play black jack until they closed the table and told me I had to move.  Really?

If they're going to charge over $100 person (that's with chips and a seat for the first act of the show) they need to learn to entertain people and allow the audience to have fun.  

I've been following Boxcar Theatre for years and have even been to two other Speakeasy experiences that were insanely awesome.  This time around they are focusing too much on the poorly written script and bad acting without letting the audience actually have a good time.

I'm so sad with this production I could cry.  Where is the elegance and amazing artistic expression Boxcar created with Hedwig?
author: Lara W.

description: My husband and I did this for our anniversary.  It was really fun, we were seated in the bar to start, then saw the cabaret show.  Spent a little time in the casino.  It was fun to try and follow the storyline.  We only stayed until 10:30 or so and still thought it was worth the price.  They really play up the mystery of the location.  One of our best date nights in a long time!
author: Jeanette L.

description: My friend invited me.  The event itself was marvelous, however we wouldn't go back and wouldn't recommend it based off their customer service.   My friend was charged for drinks that were never received, and the company would refund or resolve these charges.  My friend contacted them three times and the issue wasn't corrected. We are really disappointed about this bad customer service.  The event was mind-blowing, but the service is not.  Beware if you you go that you're getting charged for what you get!
author: Chloe B.

description: The ambiance at The Speakeasy is incredible. You really feel like you've gone back in time. The cocktails are excellent and the music authentic. The full theatrical experience of the event is so hard to describe because every time you go, you'll have a different experience. I expect I'll be returning again and again. And I look forward to introducing all my friends to this amazing time warp.
author: David A R.

description: It was so much fun! And we definitely gonna go back there soon in the future, cause it's almost impossible to follow all the story lines in one night, and we want to know. Since it's pricy, so we will keep it as a treat to special occasions.
author: Emily Y.

description:
Amazing show. 
Just amazing.
Seriously, it's art. Go expecting art. I was so moved by the whole thing. 
(If you simply want to hang out in a unique club, well-- I mean, you can do that if you want, but I don't recommend it. I think that very mindset might be behind some of the bad reviews-- that and maybe some bad luck.)

Good suggestions from a stranger: 1) go expecting art, 2) eat a full meal beforehand, 3) wear comfortable shoes, 4) start in the cabaret, 5) notice that the show doesn't really get going until everyone has arrived and the seats are full, 6) drink some, but not too much, 7) pick a character and try to follow them (you'll likely fail, but that's okay), and most importantly, 8) be open.
author: Michael H.

description:
Last night I went to SpeakeasySF! What a GREAT show! So many dressed in costume, complete immersive theater experience, drama, music, dancing girls, gambling and booze!! What an incredible night! It's in previews now and already selling out!!
Go see it!!! So worth every penny!
#SpeakeasySF #Speakeasy #Immersive #Awesome #20s
author: Eileen A.

description:
I did not see the first iterations of Speakeasy but as a big fan of interactive theater I was excited for this production. Ultimately I was not disappointed; it's terrific entertainment, despite having begun in the bar and bearing witness to an overly heavy handed skit of post world war one angst. That was a brief uh! oh! moment where my friends and I were a tiny bit concerned. Moving forward: the actors are really quite talented and focused. The cabaret was hilariously corny and slapstick. The chorus girls were curvy and almost kewpie like. How did they find so many dancers without tattoos? Velma the chanteuse was like seeing Catharine Zeta Jones in Chicago. And the MC? We loved him! The set design is worthy. The flow between rooms is a mite awkward but did not stop our progress.

The casino might be better served by allowing the guests to play a bit more without violent character interactions. Frankly, what stops me from giving the whole show 5 stars is the raging blast of aggro negativity that is present in many scenes. Jeesh! Keep it real but don't bring my night down with a headache from screaming pissed off actors. I know alot about the early 20's. Definitely not all wine and roses. WWI took a whole generation of young men. But the depression was not yet here. People had jobs and food on their plates. There was love and fun and I would appreciate a few more story lines where this comes in. I wish they'd call me! I write historical fiction. I've got some delicious ideas.
author: Lynka A.

description:
You are all a lost generation
- Gertrude Stein in conversation


There is no doubt in my mind that Hemingway's poignant epigraph in, The Sun Also Rises, (along with writers such as Fitzgerald) has - in many ways informed the overall aesthetic of The Speakeasy's narrative. With such source material in mind, one should expect an examination of the zeitgeist of the "Roaring twenties", replete with all its existential angst in a full blown, operatic format. Setting such gravitas aside, there is an occasional breath of fresh air in terms of comedy - but there is no doubt that much of the comedic relief is still understandably dark in nature.

Overall, I felt the experience to be mostly well polished and immersive.It was a very enjoyable experience and I would highly recommend to anyone looking for an immersive theatre experience. Also, as many others have noted - one should go dressed in period attire.
author: Kevin N.

description:
The best night of are life's. The production and atmosphere was top notch. My wife and I where entertained and loved exploring the plots. A must bye all to enjoy this amazing show/event/history lesson. 
Give Dorothy my love!

New show in November 2016.
author: Raymond C.

description: My friends and I had a wonderful night at the Speakeasy! You really feel like you're transported back in time to the 1920's. The details of the location were amazing and the actors were excellent. There was a good balance of comedy and drama.  Make sure to look for the hidden doors! I would recommend dressing up in 20's fashion to truly feel like you're part of that time. If you appreciate old movies and classic Hollywood glamour or just history, this is a place to go.
author: Ying L.

description: What a great experience and such a great idea. This interactive play is immersive and feels like you are stepping back into time. You don't know what to expect and I can see how it would be different every time you visit. Michael at the roulette table (7/8/17) was a great teacher of roulette and black jack. The premise is a little confusing, but now I know what to expect so I'd definitely go back and follow the characters.
author: lucy c.

description:
I love all speakeasy things.

This review is more of a 3.5. We took our friends as an early christmas gift experience and we had such a great time getting dolled up roaring 20's style.

The evening did not start off smooth - the original instructions on the webpage that was sent the day before had the wrong instructions. When I arrived at the check in point, the security and staff said I was at the wrong place and looked at me as if I couldn't follow instructions. 

Turns out they had the incorrect meeting place and clue. Updated their webpage with the new instructions, of course, the day after I got my instructions.

Especially, with a member in our party who had a disability and we had to walk to different places, it was a little tough. Some front door and back door people were not in character, so it would have been better if they were.

Once we got in, the rest of the night was pretty interesting. Always something going on. Guessing who are the actors vs. patrons. Stories unveiled around us. I'm keeping this vague so you can discover your own experience.

The casino, bar, restroom and other rooms are hidden, so you won't see clear signs of where to go.

Hope they get their logistics and check-in process better.

Tips:
- Don't go with any expectations- keep your mind open
- No need to reserve seats - save your $$
- Explore all the corners, rooms and places

It wasn't a 5 star experience (for the price) but it was a unique novel SF thing to do if you don't have any expectations going in. 

If you go, enjoy!
author: Vanae W.

description:
Incredible transportation to the time period of the 1920s! Dress UP, drink up, and engage yourself with talent and a true experience that will make you forget you're in San francisco. 
Love it!
Purchase tickets online well ahead of time!
author: Veranna N.

description:
I'm absolutely addicted to interactive theatre experiences and even kickstarted this Boxcar Theatre endeavor when it popped up on my FB many moons ago. I've been looking forward to checking out The Speakeasy since I got their email at the beginning of the year, and even bought a plane ticket specifically to go to this little shindig. 

So with all those disclaimers out of the way...

Their last performances are in June (special deals for Wed night), so give yourself this little indie theatre treat before they leave the building. If you think you're familiar with this type of experience, you'll be surprised. I was.

This is a much smaller and more intimate production than Temple Studios' shows like Speak No More. So comparisons are unwarranted. You're also not a masked figure here. The characters can see you. So it's not trying to be the same thing at all.

So here's what I got: 8 PM tickets with assigned table seating, one bag of poker chips, and two slots for the after-party. All totally worth it.

8 PM entry was perfect. All patrons are actually expected to enjoy the cabaret for a set amount of time before the "show" truly begins and you're led into the other rooms. Since you can't really wander until the cabaret completes, 8 PM gives you time to sample the stage show, enjoy a few drinks, and get yourself situated into the pageantry of it all.

**Note: Your ticket time changes where you actually enter. 8 PM patrons go through a different door than earlier patrons. It's a very nice touch on their part to have multiple points of entry.

They stagger individual parties when giving directions from the start point. I appreciate this, so you don't just end up following one another. It's actually a little adventure in and of itself just trying to find the speakeasy in the first place. So the atmosphere is being built up even before you arrive. When we first questioned a certain individual on where to go, there were actually quite a few other patrons dressed up and mulling around (to the interest of many passer-by's), waiting for their opportunity to ask for the same help. So don't wait for someone to walk up to you, they won't. You'll have to take initiative.

In response to some reviews:

- Yes. The drinks all taste the same and are borderline unpalatable. Consider that most illegal alcohol was bathtub gin and moonshine, and you'll begin to appreciate the rather authentic experience, haha. Though kudos to the bartender for whipping up a few concoctions "more suitable for a lady."

- Yes, the cabaret show is cheesy and irritating. I honestly think that's because in this created world, the speakeasy is run by a sleazy proprietor who dominates his generally meek stage girls, conceals a dirty casino in a back room, and could care less about your "good time." It makes sense to the context of the story that these aren't first-rate acts.

Definitely stay for the after-party, if only for an hour. Though it was so much fun, we ended up staying till they kicked us out... Not only will it give you a deeper appreciation for what goes into this show, you'll also get a chance to mingle with the actors and staff (more than 80 people make this show happen each night), have many of your curiosities answered, see the scenery in a different light, and take pictures inside. So dress to the 10s.

--

My suggestions to the production should they decide to apply this concept elsewhere in the future:

1) Slow motion during particular soliloquies was a nice touch. However, not all actors were doing their part to maintain this effect, and it was lost to more than a few people. The bartender (and casino dealers, etc) should also be affected. You can time it so he's speaking with a particular character before another's monologue starts up. If he's taking an order or conversing with a patron, have another actor interrupt the exchange and get his attention.

2) What you need for the next production are speakers linked with microphones on the actors. Definitely get a good sound engineer. That way, their voices penetrate into the room and are audible to even the casual listener. Even after putting a spotlight on the characters and gathering the audience's attention, lots of dialogue was lost to the crowd many times. For me in the lounge area, even while seated on the chaise, it was difficult to deliberately listen to the conversation happening at the bistro table directly adjacent.

3) Lastly, I know that many of you have clown and improv schooling. Still, given the direct face-to-face interaction, this is the type of show that requires an actor to be on their toes all night. And a few of you need to work on how to gracefully flub lines. When you respond to a verbal stumble by correcting yourself, you draw the more discerning patrons out of this carefully constructed fairytale. Don't worry about repeating your lines the same every time. It's about effectively getting your character's point across. Sell that and you're set.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
I had an amazing time! I've seen a lot of unconventional theater, but I'd never been to an immersive production before. I was totally blown away.

A few notes:

I got my tickets using the TodayTix app, and they were WAY cheaper that way. (Still a bit of a splurge, but not nearly as much as the face value.) You can only book up to a week or two in advance, but it seems like they almost always have tickets if you check the weekend before you plan on going. You also don't get to choose your starting location like you would if you bought them on the website, but the box office was happy to oblige when I called the day before and asked to be seated in the cabaret.

That said, the starting location doesn't matter all that much. I requested the cabaret because I was worried I wouldn't get to see it otherwise, but there were plenty of open seats throughout the night. After the first forty minutes or so, you can spend as much time as you want in any of the other areas.

I was surprised by how much of the action took place outside of the "main" rooms. I'd recommend spending some time exploring the hallways, because you'll likely come across a secret room or a scene you'd otherwise miss. 

Unless you make a point of following one particular storyline, you're going to get bits and pieces of a lot of storylines. I thought this would be confusing, but the story arcs were surprisingly easy to follow even if you miss some parts. 

The drinks are expensive, but good. I had a Manhattan and a Velvet Sea, and really liked them both. As other reviewers have mentioned, it's best to eat before you get there. The food is really pricey if you want anything more than a small snack.

I was a little skeptical about the no phones rule, but I didn't miss my phone at all. (For those who are wondering, they make you keep all electronics in a sealed bag.) It really added to the authenticity of the night, and anyway, you wouldn't have your phone out during a more conventional theater performance, would you?

Stay until the end. I don't want to give away the ending, but it's worth staying for.
author: Ruby B.

description:
Shady Shady Shady! I have never written a yelp review in my life, but The Speakeasy deserves to be called out on their shady business practice.  

I don't want this review to downplay the actual experience, because the show was great and my problem has nothing to do with production. My issue is being overcharged and management trying to blame the customer! They made up some fake story about how the male manager remembered our table and how once he explained the menu to us we 'excitedly' ordered the better bottle of champagne. The thing is, we had a female server who did not explain the menu to us, as the show had started and she could barely hear us. On top of that, they are charging us for bottles of Champagne we did not drink, we had Gloria Ferrer and the bill says Roederer Estate. The argument is over $40.00 so it's beyond me why they are being SO difficult. For us, it's the principle. Whats right is right, and I don't appreciate being ripped off.
author: Megan P.

description:
First of all, people need to stop comparing this show to Sleep No More. It's not the same. Stop it. 

I don't understand how anyone could have had a bad time here. It was so much fun! So many people to see and stories to follow. Drinks were great. The casino was a perfect break from following stories. I loved it and want to go again/will go again.
author: Brittany U.

description: There is NOTHING like this show! Before we even got in the venue, we were invited into the world of The Speakeasy - the glamour, glitz, grit, and grime. It felt super fun to be "in" on it all (and dressed the part, too!) - as if we had a secret from others walking around North Beach - and it made for a playful date night. Once inside, we were totally swept away. The characters' stories were thoughtful and engaging, and the acting was superb. We didn't know who to follow as the night unfolded! You could see this show 30 times and pick up something new each time. Keep an eye out for secret rooms and passageways - magic abounds here and the place is full of surprises! We'll be going back for sure.
author: Angela H.

description: This was definitely a one of a kind experience! We went back in time from the moment we stepped in...From the amazing characters to the mindblowing costumes. So much to take in and enjoy. I strongly recommend dressing for the era. It was so great not knowing who were actors or guest. I must go back again and follow different characters...loved it!
author: Angie O.

description: Absolutely amazing! The ambiance and cast were fantastic. Guests dress enough in period clothing it was difficult to figure out who was part of the show...until someone got punched in the face. I'm looking forward to visiting again
author: Kevin K.

description: Expensive and not worth it. The idea is fun, but the execution was poor. Not very organized. We spent almost an hour gambling. No one said we could go to another room and watch the concert, etc. Our phones were confiscated so we were unable to take any pictures, yet no one informed us that we could take a picture (for additional $$). When we decided to gamble, we were told we had to pay for it, $10 per person. However, you can't cash out the winnings, because it's illegal. I don't understand why, after paying a $75 entrance fee, we had to pay an additional price  for the fake gamble! Anyways, we didn't care much for this.
author: E N.

description: This is the most amazing evening (3 times so far ! ) I have ever spent.  This show is breathtaking, and deserves to be a very permanent part of the SF theater scene.  I got a secret password.   I dressed in pearls.  I 86'd my cell phone.  I met a gal in a doorway in North Beach.  I followed a map.  And I was literally immersed into a Prohibition-era speakeasy : a casino, a cabaret, a bar.  The amazing action took place all around me, and sometimes...I was the action.   The cast is top-rate, the sheer jaw-dropping entertainment is non-stop.  You never see the same show twice - which explains my seeing it again and again.  Posiitively the best theater experience SF has to offer.  I just can't urge you enough to see this show.  Seriously.
author: Mary N.

description: I attended during preview month, and wrote a good review. I attended again this month, and need to update my review to reflect the excellence I experienced five months into the run. Wow!!! It is a terrific, seamless show where the audience is enthusiastically invited into the world of the 1920s...and the lives of some fascinating characters. It is moving, inspiring, sad, poignant, and joyful. I cannot recommend it highly enough. Don't hesitate - bring everyone from locals to out of town guests, and go see for yourself! Truly a memorable evening.
author: Tanya R.

description: One of the greatest theater experiences I've ever had. I could go again and again and again! You really get immersed in the era. Just wander from room to room and you'll experiences one of the best theatrical performances around. Amazing acting, amazing story, great drinks, just can't say enough good about this place. From beginning to the end, just perfectly done.
author: Clay L.

description: Lame and boring! DID NOT LIVE UP TO THE HYPE. I paid extra to be the winning racehorse owner which came with a heavy wool costume that didn't fit and was way too warm. The storylines were pointless and the ambiance was cheesy. The Caberet was like a bad Vaudeville show; let's just say there's a reason why people stop going to those shows. The only fun I did have was in the casino but since the dealers were all actors and not real dealers, the play was slow and sloppy. By the end of the night, the storylines became more and more annoying. We also ordered THREE ROUNDS of drinks that never showed up. This place is a colossal waste of money!!! SKIP IT!!!
author: Mitchell S.

description: OVER CHARGED on bar bill. We ordered 2 bottles of champs; on the menu the price was $40 but we were billed for $60 bottles that were not even available on the menu. After bringing this up with the manager, after waiting weeks for him to respond... he told me I was mistaken on what I order??? Really...were you there? BE AWARE!
author: Erica G.

description: Thank you SpeakEasy for all your effort to create such an experience. There are definitely kinks that need to be worked out, but all in all, I'd recommended this to anyone.  Yes, it's expensive, but you're getting a +3hr personalized experience with loads of actors!  I love that EVERYONE dressed for the occasion.  Good luck to you SpeakEasy!
author: Kat M.

description: Amazing time! Compelling, unique, fascinating, fun... highly recommend it. Details not forthcoming; that would spoil it.
author: david l.

description:
It was a fun experience but have to downgrade them for overcharging me for drinks. You basically run a tab and they charge your credit card and email you the bill so the waitress thought the lady sitting next to my husband was with us so her wine ended up on my tab! I am trying to get it fixed but if you decide to go would make sure you only pay for what you really did drink!
A!so don't bother with the wine- it does taste like it was made in the basement. The cocktails are much better!

I have amended my rating as they did get back to me and have corrected the bill. Thank you!
author: Barbara H.

description: I went to the Speakeasy with a friend tonight and we were underwhelmed. I have been to a number of immersive theatre events in New York when I lived there and absolutely loved them so I was excited to go to Speakeasy. One of the things I loved about the experiences I had prior was the staff was alluring, adventurous, inviting, and intriguing. This was not the case at Speakeasy. Staff were cordial like they would be at a restaurant. We began the evening in the bar and listened to several conversations which were a bit dull at first then picked up some interesting historical significance later on. Okay, maybe this will be fun we thought. Then we went to the casino where we were encouraged to play craps, which we did, then lost all our money which is to be expected. The cabaret was the next room which was entertaining but not so much that we wanted to stay more than ten minutes. We didn't find any secret rooms or have any real engagement with the staff. We stayed three hours, all in all we both felt it was kind of meh. It's certainly better than sitting at a bar but definitely not the kind of fun immersive theatre we were hoping for.
author: Lauren M.

description: What a great event! Date night with the hubby as we travelled through time back to the roaring 20s'  We just loved the entire event! Multiple interactive events under one underground. The actors/actresses/singers are all great.
author: The Sun '.

description:
The speakeasy is not only a show, but an adventure. From the clandestine meeting on the corner to back alleys, back staircases ,right into the authentic 20s cabaret show, we were hooked. The cabaret show was complete  with MC ,dancing girls in lovely outfits and the beginnings of some vignettes . Also enjoyed the table games in the casino,though it hard to follow the dramas there  The best find though, was in the lounge,  a room it's possible to miss (a  friend did) .There we were  caught up in multiple unfolding dramas with the aspiring writer Charlotte, she was completely engaging and at one point we actually actually followed her into the restroom for a more private hearing of her torrid novel. We kind of felt like a part of the in crowd.  
 
Really appreciated the historical and local references throughout the play. It  helped to give  sense of reality for the times and place and there were  some interesting details ,like the turned out pockets of the homeless being called Hoover flags.

 There were also some musical highs.The guys in the casino gave a great rendition of "Solidarity Forever", and in the final scene, in the bar, the combined group and solo singing of "Those Werethe Days " ,was really moving. We  didn't want it to end, and will definitely be back again.
author: Jc W.

description: My boyfriend and I really enjoyed this interactive theater performance.  It was a Christmas gift and we didn't know what to expect -- it was really fun to get dressed up and be immersed in an interactive experience where we didn't know what was coming next.  I really loved the decor and the authenticity of the 1920's environment- we loved playing at the Casino and hanging around at the bar watching the actors.  I wish they had a dance floor with some ragtime- that would have upped the anty.  It was a bit hard to keep up with the storylines and sometimes to hear the actors.  Also there were a variety of acting levels so not everyone had noticeable talent (hence the drop in a star given the price), but those that did were really entertaining!  I definitely recommend for anyone that enjoys the arts and looking for a fun new way to spend a weekend evening!
author: Stephanie S.

description: O.M.G.!! The best fun ever! My birthday celebration continues!  My sister-in-law and I were transported back to a 1920's Prohibition Era Speak Easy.  We were prepared, in appropriate costumes, as well as others attending. In fact, sometimes difficult to pick out the actors from the audience! This is total immersion theatre!  No modern gadgets allowed! Cell phones are turned off, sealed and put away. Do your selfies before and/or after. There are on going performances in ALL the areas ALL the time and flowing back and forth from secret entrances to bar or was it from casino? to Cabaret, to the hustle and bustle in the corridor with viewing windows to the "Boss'" office. Be sure to pick up the telephone to secretly listen in on their conversation! I walked into a whole scene in the Powder Room!  Wow!  How do they manage for hours in character, non stop??!!  It's secretive on how you get in and with different maps and entrances.  I loved it!  Who's interested in coming with me next time I go?  (Because you know, I'm going back!!)
author: Christina V.

description:
What an awesome show! My husband and I had a great time here on a Friday night. We almost didn't buy tickets because it's so pricey, but we're so glad we did.

You definitely feel immersed in the era, from the old-timey decor to the costumes and the storylines -- of which there are many to follow, from young WWI vets trying to move on with their lives, to dancers in the chorus line working to pay off their family's gambling debts, to the cutthroat wife of the speakeasy's owner arranging to have someone bumped off. Aside from the three main rooms - the cabaret, the casino, and the bar - you can eavesdrop on the dealings of the speakeasy's owner in his office, and watch various dramas unfold in the dancers' dressing room or in the tucked-away sitting room. I wish we could go again just to catch up with the rest of the characters.

Oh, and I loved all of the references to SF history -- the 1906 earthquake, Alma Spreckels, President Harding's death at the Palace Hotel, etc.

Nitpicks: When we arrived at the bar, it was overcrowded and there was only standing room for a while. Because of that, it took over an hour just to order our first drink. I have no idea if that's a regular thing, but maybe start at the casino or cabaret to be safe. Also, the after-party was pretty empty and it seemed mostly like a decompression time for the actors, so you're not missing much if you skip it.

All in all, a super unique and fun way to spend a night in the city.
author: Kat H.

description: First off the space itself is incredible. Every single detail replicates the 1920s - literally everything.  Stepping into the cabaret is simply breathtaking. You feel like you have travelled back in time nearly 100 years. For the ambience alone it's worth a visit. Then there's the entertainment - amazing actors and a fun cabaret show. Top it off with great cocktails. This was one of the most unique and exhilarating experiences I have ever had in San Francisco (and we're in SF of course). Truly one of the most well crafted theater productions and experiences. Just go ... and tell your friends as well. Thank you Speakeasy SF for making such an amazing production!
author: Kate D.

description: Easily one of my favorite experiences in the city of 2016. Amazing set design, performances, drinks, costumes, story lines, and music. Such a great experience, especially since everyone's so beautifully dressed that it's not even worth asking who is on the performance and whose not. Be sure to stay to the very end, too ;)
author: Lorena M.

description: We were absolutely BLOWN AWAY with the entire experience! The staff was entertaining, the stories amazing and the opportunity to be taken to a different time; priceless. I was moved to  tears by the two soldiers story told in the bar, moved to laugh out loud by the salesman at the bar, fell in love a little with the cabaret cast and wouldn't change a single thing. I felt personally connected to all of the player and the hooch took me for quite the ride! Thank you for making our journey back in time a priceless memory...
author: Paige H.

description: This is one of those unique experiences that is not to be missed.  Everything about it is secretive like the old speakeasys were and you truly feel transported back in time.  The immersive theater going on all around you is adds realism and information about those times in our history.  Be sure to dress up, it contributes to the fun.
author: Linda S.

description:
Such a fun night -- we didn't want it to end! The space is just the right size to explore and know that there's always interesting things happening wherever you are. Having a mental map of the space also makes it easier to follow characters from room to room or follow up on a hunch you have about something that might happen. The acting was great (especially the MC of the cabaret -- hilarious). Interesting characters and storylines, and all well-themed for the era. The live music was a surprising treat.

To us, the casino was the least interesting room, so I'd recommend not buying chips in advance. You can always get them there if you want to, but we were so busy following stories that we never ended up using the chips we bought.

I made the mistake of re-reading the Yelp reviews for this right before the performance, and they were so negative that it actually had me a little less excited to go. But my experience was very different from those, e.g. we were never shh'd because we were engrossed in the performance and rarely talked, the dark scene referred to in the bar was my favorite of the whole performance, etc.

Having experienced Sleep No More, there are definitely similarities but many more differences, nearly all positive in my opinion. One I'll call out specifically is that it's very enjoyable whether you're a story chaser or just want to relax in one room for a period of time and let the entertainment come to you. Chasing stories is rewarding, but it's also very fun to just enjoy things as they happen in each room. I highly recommend going, and will likely go again myself to follow different characters next time.

The only 2 negative experiences that I'll share in hopes the feedback is useful to the show are:
1. The check in process was chaos and needs to change. Our telegram said to show up on time and be discreet, and with staggered entry times we assumed it would be well-coordinated, so we killed a few minutes to show up exactly at our appointed time. We wanted to be discreet and not approach while the staff member was talking to others as requested, but after 4-5 other groups cut ahead of us we ended up having to stand right next to them to prevent any other groups from cutting ahead of us, which means we heard the same jokes and spiel several time. We ended up wasting 15 minutes trying to get checked in (while the other staff members had no wait at all), which is 15 more minutes we should have been enjoying the performance. As a result, I entered the performance very annoyed, which is definitely not the mood you want to be in for this.

2. Without spoiling anything, the scene in the cabaret that involves a lot of audience participation made no sense. Why work so hard to maintain the 1920s theme and then ruin it like that? We were both really confused after that and what it was supposed to accomplish.
author: Justin S.

description:
We had a wonderful experience and I'm thankful that we were only mildly informed as to what to expect. It's best to be suprised and roll with whatever drama unfolds. I was also glad this was not an audience participation event, other than dressing in the attire of the period.
I'd love to go back because there is no way you can soak it all in the first time.
author: Joe K.

description: An absolutely magical experience. Top notch in all categories. You feel completely immersed in the world they put you in and if you're lucky, they might involve you in the inner workings of the show and storylines. A perfect date night and I would recommend to anyone and everyone. Worth every penny.
author: Jim T.

description:
Huge disappointment. The employee on the phone who we bought tickets from exclaimed this would blow Sleep No More out of the water. Opposite was true - this is cheesy community theater that pales next to the real production values of Sleep No More. 

To start, the space is incredibly small. It's not even the size of 1 of the 4 floors for Sleep No More. It's essentially 3 rooms plus 1 standing area. We had seen all of the areas within an hour and aimlessly wandered the rest of the night trying to find something interesting to watch. 

The theater room is the best part, but if you don't pay the $10 up charge for reserved seats, they won't even let you in. The rules weren't made clear so we initially entered and stood in the back. The host immediately asked us to leave as there's apparently no standing. We came back later, and when they finally offered us some seats out of pity, we were immediately kicked out by actors who needed the seats. It's crazy to pay over $100 for a base ticket and need to pay up-charges to see the full show. Given how small the space is, this just doesn't work. Suggest they drop the up-charge entirely or add a large block of free seating. 

Acting varies. The worst part was when they tried to imitate Sleep No More with dramatic physical scenes. It was so stilted and uncomfortable that our group had to look away. 

There is also nothing to explore or interact with. They advised us not to go into any areas marked private but didn't do a thorough job of marking all of the off-limits spaces. Best part was a group that discovered an elevator behind a curtain. They took it up, and a minute later, joined us again after it took them nowhere. I also found a small, unmarked door and opened it up, only to discover a young actor waiting in the dressing room for his scene. Add in all of the rules around seating in the theater and a grumpy security guard who tossed out our friend's bottled water while grunting "It's 1923" - interactive this is not. 

And the worst offense is the show is way too long. It's over 3.5 hours, and as it inched past 11:00, I looked up to the balcony to see an employee passed out asleep. Smart guy. Wanting to do the same, we tracked down our friends who confirmed they were tired too and we bolted for the front door. We ended up interrupting a scene outside the entrance as we struggled to find our coats in the dark. An actor did break character to help us find our stuff - our escape ended up the most interactive and exciting part of the night. 

It is true we saw the show while it's still in previews and that they have time to tweak some items I mention above (marking all off-limit areas, better seating in the theater, asking employees not to fall asleep on the job) but the core issues are endemic. The space is too small, the dialog hammy, and the story wholly uninteresting. And when the most memorable part of the night is a group ending up on a service elevator to nowhere, the show is a failure. 

Save your money to see Sleep No More when you're in NYC. This is one speakeasy that's better left underground.
author: Brian K.

description: Absolutely a ball.  We went as a special surprise treat for my husband's birthday, but this would be suitable for anyone looking for just a fun night out.  The other attendees dressed the part, which makes it so much more fun.  The "experience" was rich and non-stop.  I rented my dress from Decades of Fashion on Haight street - $127, all in. (My experience there was five star, BTW.) Our friend went to a costume shop for his 20's "suit".  Laughably, my husband owns a 20's suit.  We started in the Bar.  The cabaret was also excellent.  I don't care for Casino-type things much, but many people were in that room.  It was great fun.  Highly recommend.
author: Bobbi C.

description: This is San Francisco's biggest secret that everyone needs to know about. I was looking to take my girlfriend somewhere special our anniversary date and I heard from a friend of a friend about this entertainment venue called " The SpeakEasy SF". It's fully immersive theatrical experience that transport you back in time to the early 1920's. This is a formal attire (Roaring 20's/Steampunk cosplay) exploration into what it would have been like to drink, gamble and watch a true vaudevillian experience. When we entered this "WestWorld like" world of illicit gangsters and sexy showgirls through a secret passageway behind an old fashioned clock (pretty cool). Everyone's experience is different depending on where you choose to begin. What really surprised me was they even let us peek backstage in the dressing rooms and we could watch and listen to the dancers before and after they hit the stage. It's like watching a play that completely surrounds you and you can walk anywhere and experience a different parts of the overarching storyline. Every time you enter the SpeakEasy it's a different experience depending on what and where you choose to watch. There is nothing in the world like this. This is the best way to feel what's it like to live in the 1920's short of being on the Star Trek Enterprise's holodeck. Must see to believe!
author: Michael I.

description:
We attended the original Speakeasy and had a great time. But this new version is at a whole different level! It is really the perfect evening. Everyone comes dressed up in swanky 1920's attire (or the best they can do) and as we wait to enter the top secret location,  there is this immediate atmosphere of excitement. As soon as you enter into the space it is like you are teleported back to the 1920's. They have done an incredible job building romantic, authentic interiors. 

We began in the cabaret which was really well done. The MC was your classic cabaret MC, with a white painted face, telling jokes fitting for the 1920's. The chorus girls were fantastic! It's great that you can get cocktails of the time period at any time as well.

From there we got to experience the casino (did well gambling:) and explored all these other amazing little rooms they have set up where you will stumble upon scenes that happen around you. Sometimes you get pulled into the action, sometimes you just witness a beautiful artsy, out of time dance moment, sometimes you hear beautiful dialogue as two characters fight in a room that you can only see through a small window. 

One of the most magical, effective, and fun evenings I've had in a while. It may be pricey, but it's really like getting a costume party, a night out at a bar, a night at a casino, a theatre show, and a concert all at once. Oh yeah and an exciting history lesson!!!
author: Miranda J.

description:
Please don't miss this. It represents everything I love about a city full of spirit and creativity. 

Resolve to get into it, dress up, explore, look around you. It's supremely well done and there are details and clues to the story everywhere.

I've already said too much.
author: D Z.

description: What a GREAT evening! Even my husband, who's not into theater or dressing up, enjoyed it! Don't worry about paying extra for reserved seats on the cabaret- you'll see just fine. Share a bag of poker chips among your friends. Order some of the delicious drinks! Feel free to enter on the late side of things- you'll still see it all! I can't wait to go back again! A very unique San Francisco experience! VERY well written and choreographed, as the performers move between rooms.
author: W C.

description: An outstanding level of production, attention to smallest detail - just wow! I think it's the first truly immersive theatrical performance I've been to.
author: Xenia E.

description:
Full disclosure: we went to one of the performances that was considered a test performance and the organization admitted that since they were refining the experience there may be technical problems.  There were, in fact technical problems, mainly related to lighting and cues, but I got the sense at multiple points that even with the kinks worked out, this would not be a polished, buttoned-down experience.

A few cast members were great, but other casting was not so great.  It was supposed to be a period experience (1920's themed) but the actors rarely demonstrated speech or mannerisms that seemed convincing.  They missed opportunities to invest more money in wardrobes that would have been convincing.  There was a casino element to it and those cast as dealers were slow and barely showed proficiency in the games, especially blackjack.  When I tried to tip a dealer with a chip, instead of remaining in character, she laughed and reminded me that it was fake money. 

It simply wasn't a cohesive experience.  There was no real plot, and it wasn't clear when the experience was supposed to end.  Visitors are instructed aggressively to speak only when spoken to by a cast member, but there was not very much opportunity to interact because it was so scripted.  By the end, I understood what they were trying to do and how it was supposed to feel, but it simply missed the mark.

Finally, This was a mediocre experience for the price.  Tickets were around $100 apiece.  Drinks were yummy but small and ~$13 apiece with mandatory gratuity.  Gambling chips ere $10 per person, and dinner wasn't served.  The two of us spent a total of about $300 on the experience itself and by the time we paid for a babysitter and grabbed something to eat afterward, it was a $500 date.

I wanted to like it--I really did, and I had a good time because I always have a good time with my husband but it could have been better.  With some big changes, it still could be.
author: Kim W.

description: What a fun experience. They've done such a great job with the writing. You'll definitely want to go back because you can't possibly follow all the various story lines that are taking place simultaneously.
author: Jamie G.

description: My friends and I recently returned to Speakeasy for the 3rd time, celebrating a friend's birthday. The show has always left us seriously impressed by the quality of the characters, story, music, and atmosphere. Though some of the storylines are indeed dark (PTSD experienced by a WWI veteran, parents of a soldier grieving the loss of their son in the war, gambling addiction, etc.) some of the characters are hilarious and witty, too. This mix creates, to me, a more authentic feel. Do reserve seats in the cabaret for at least one part of the night: the MC and singers and dancers are not to be missed. And make sure you dress to the nines, preferably in period attire, as they don't let you in if you look like a bum (nor should they). Decades of Fashion on Haight Street has a fantastic collection of Gatsby-worthy dresses and most guys can get away with a normal suit with a cool bow tie (perhaps topped by a fedora or bowler).
author: Mishka L.

description:
I was fortunate to experience a wonderful evening with an immersion theater experience. It is unique and amazing. I particularly enjoyed the musical performances by the actor who created Velma's character.
I recommend this show to anyone that wants fun and a real feeling of being part of the event.
author: Margaret W.

description:
Now I know that I'll get a lot of people in trouble with this here review, but I've got a voice and I need to use it.

I get my kicks at this speakeasy, you hear? And I'm not afraid to tell the world: it's the most happenest place to be.

They've got stiff drinks, plenty of talent on the stage and a nice little room where you can make some extra dough, if you know what I mean... ;)

Sure, the drama's high and some of the characters are a little shady, but hey, when you ain't got much going on in a dry town, good whiskey and questionable conversation is doin' alright.

Nevertheless, make sure to get all dolled up and head on down to... 
...
...
...come to think of if, maybe I'm not gonna get yous in trouble after all... 

The Speakeasy is a roaming production and while Joe's Clock Shop was the storefront for a long time, you'll need special instructions to get in. 

Heck, you're gonna need a password to even find Joe's. 

And yeah, good luck finding *that* guy...
author: Candice T.

description: After settling in it was fun to immerse into the various stories around us and occasionally go to the casino to play craps (something I have been interested to learn).  It was enjoyable getting dressed up as well to play along.  We purchased a table for the night as there were four (4) of us, but after initially sitting down on the first session, I realized that we did not need to reserve that table.  There are some food snacking but don't count on it for a full meal.  By the end of the event, one can begin to feel inside the moment of the 1920s prohibition.
author: Consumer M.

description:
Decent, enjoyable show but I have a few complaints about it. Honestly if I hadn't seen Sleep No More first I probably would have thought this was better, but unfortunately it didn't come close to SNM. Sorry to make the comparison but I can't really help it.. I went in expecting an intense, interactive experience and even though I had a good time, I was left wanting something more.

Pros:
* Loved that everyone was dressed up and the atmosphere was immersive. It's a truly fantastic concept and they did a great job with the set, costumes, and acts.
* Lively vibe. Don't have to stay quiet the whole time. You can talk all you want in the casino.
* Drinks everywhere. They were pretty good too. A little pricey but you'd expect that.
* The cabaret host guy was awesome. Some other great actors also.

Cons:
* Entry. The concept of meeting up with a stranger who tells you how to get in is obviously intended to invoke the speakeasy feeling, but the execution was terrible. What ends up happening is there is a large group of people lined up in the street waiting to talk to the dudes... definitely not authentic speakeasy experience. And of course there were idiots that cut the line, and it seemed like our entry times didn't matter at all. Also the actor you meet up with did the same speech about the rules for everyone and it really slowed things down. Not to mention you can hear him doing the speech like 5 times over because you're waiting in line close to him.. so goofy. They need to make it more efficient by a) staggering entry times more; b) having more people to meet up with and in locations farther apart from each other; and/or c) shorten the speech or figure out a way to give the speech to multiple groups at once.
* Initial act. We were in the cabaret first, which I imagine is the best choice because you have acts to watch. It just seemed to go on for a long time and we found ourselves wondering when the 'real' show would start and when we'd be able to go around an interact. We thought having an early entry time would give us more time to explore (this was the case for SNM) but really it just meant we sat in the cabaret longer until everyone was given leave to walk around at the same time.
* So small. Only 3 main rooms, a hallway, 1 small 'hidden' room, and 1 small room you can look in but can't go in. Felt super tiny compared to SNM, like you were done seeing everything there was to see in a half hour.
* Very few interactive set pieces and things to do besides walking between the 3 rooms, drinking, and waiting for acts to happen. There is minimal exploration involved, no drawers to open, nothing to read, no props to play with, no mysteries to uncover.
* Casino chips. I paid over $100 to attend this event and you can't give me a couple measly casino chips as part of my entry? You have to pay $10 extra to get some chips, and the games get boring fast considering they're games you can play anywhere (roulette, blackjack, etc), and winning means nothing. They could at least have offered some cheap little rewards or even a free drink if you win enough chips.
* I agree with another reviewer that a few of the actors/actresses did not do a good job speaking and acting in a 20's manner. 

It was a fun evening but far from mind-blowing. I think it will probably improve over time though.
author: Vee N.

description: We attended the New Year's Eve celebration and had a wonderful time. The staff was super friendly and the actors engaging and interesting.  The drinks were stiff and appetizers tasty. We had a blast and plan on attending again soon with friends.  It was a very fun way to ring in 2017.
author: Kent B.

description:
Shhhhhh....speak easy....would hate to have this little gem to be on the up high. I want to keep it all to myself....and you of course. If I could I would go to this experience every weekend...really. It makes you feel like you are in your own little movie rubbing elbows with mob bosses, runaway flappers, and bartenders that know too much or just enough. We started with the Cabaret and it was like being in an old Woody Allen film. Great cocktails, great music, singing and dancing, and great story throughout.

No one broke character and believe me, there are characters! 

Dress up - because it's fun
Get food beforehand - 3hr experience
Smile, be friendly, follow the rules and people might think you're part of it...maybe you are? ;)

Bottoms up.
author: Dan D.

description: What a beautiful space and amazing show!  So impressed!  Had a great time.
author: Natasha G.

description: Amazing time!!! The only way to explain it is you are IN THE 1920's. No phones, no worries, jsut cocktails and a great time. Perfect date night, birthday, insert any reason here. Eat before you go, there isn't food. :-)
author: Christie J.

description:
