This was a fun experience and I do recommend it for anyone who enjoys a night of cocktails, live performances, and "people watching." Although I keep hearing comparisons to Sleep No More in New York, I don't think the two fall in the same category. It is an immersive theater experience but to me it was more similar to being at the Charles Dickens Christmas Fair because there was not overarching story line. It is more along the lines of experiencing the era rather than watching play unfold.

Tips:
+Dress up in 1920s attire; it's fun and adds to the experience!
+Explore and move around everywhere you can except the areas marked "Staff Only" or "Reserved"
+Buy tickets to the after party to mingle with the actors and actresses. They are such interesting characters :)
+Don't be afraid to split up, in fact, it's more fun to go separate ways and compare notes later.
+I enjoyed having a guaranteed table at the cabaret but it looked like there were always open seats.
+Although the casino area is fun, I would recommend hanging out there only if an performers are in there or if you really love casino games that much.
+The ticketing system is a bit wonky. If it shows 2 tickets available for each entry time, it does not mean there are 2 tickets available for each time slot, it means there are 2 tickets left total and you can only choose the times still available.
+The production was said to run only until the end of March but they have been extended until end of May :)



Quick and easy wardrobe and styling suggestions:

LADIES:
Head bands
Feathers, flowers, brooches and pins
Red lipstick
smokey eyes
pin curls and victory curls
Cloche hats
Vintage or vintage style dresses from thrift shops or Forever 21


GENTS:
Suspenders
Flat cap
Trilby/Fedora/Homburg
Newsboy cap
Bowler Hat
Suit
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
I went last week and had a blast! If you're someone who enjoys interactive events you'll love the Speakeasy. If you do plan to attend, I HIGHLY recommend dressing up in 1920's clothing because it makes it feel more realistic when you look around the room and see everyone in costumes. 

Another tip is to be prepared to follow the rules- they only have a few and it helps to make the event run more smoothly. Many attendees seemed to be annoyed by the few rules they had in place, and it made it more difficult for them to move things along.
author: Hayley N.

description:
The Spekeasy is one of those things that needs to be attended in order to truly understand it, and words are not altogether enough, however I will make the attempt.

A deeply immersive experience where you're not exactly sure what will happen next, but as the evening goes on, you know it will be exciting and engrossing. Music, acting, dance, and also a  great place to practice for Vegas.

The staff is excellent, and full of character, and you feel well taken care of, and the specialty cocktails that I did try were quite top notch.

Worth going many times to kind of get a feel for what the story is, but also feel free to wander around. Partially on rails, partially create your own experience, the experience is guided enough that you don't feel at a loss for anything to do.

Just remember to keep your eyes peeled, and remember, speak easy.

Pro tip:
Ask where the restrooms are discreetly at the beginning if that's a concern, you'll want to know a few routes to go. I'll leave it at that.
author: Brian V.

description: Worst $80 I've ever spent. But actually you will spend at least $150 here because drinks are an additional $15 each and it's $35 extra to take pictures. Plus 18% tip automatically added to your tab. But that's all fine and expected. No cellphones, no talking (at all) and no fun allowed.. nobody was smiling. The acting was not funny or entertaining. The staff were so unbelievably rude. You couldn't do anything without getting yelled at and they would not break character, not even to tell us how much our drinks cost or how much poker chips were. Standing around? Not allowed, they'll come tell you to move. They brought our friend up on stage (without warning) and everyone was cheering for her. When we cheered, too, to give our friend extra support in front of all these strangers, the waitress came over and told us to be quiet because we were "ruining the night for everyone". We were not obnoxiously drunk because again, the drinks are expensive, so we only had one drink each. Our friends 25th birthday party was an epic fail because all 13 of us felt offended and like we'd wasted our money and wanted to leave. We dressed up and everything! After living in the city 4 years I now know why I hadn't been invited there before. I know they are associated with Beach Blanket Babylon so I will not be wasting my money there either.
author: Katie L.

description: Spectacular.  A must see and truly memorable experience.   Well done from start to finish.  The production quality, historical context and story flow is both subtle and engaging.
author: Stephen P.

description: WOW! It was one of the best experiences in my entire life!!! Really enjoyed everything: talented actors, singers, and dancers, how management has such great attention to detail, the whole idea of this theater! It WAS AMAZING! THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR PUTTING IT TOGETHER AND THANK YOU FOR SUCH A WONDERFUL IDEA!!!
author: Eleanor S.

description:
BOOK IT NOW! This is an experience unmatched by anything else. I was tantalized, jaw-dropped, and engaged in every magical moment. They really kept in mind all the details. And, you should be dressed accordingly. I cannot even describe this experience - you are truly transported back to the 1920's in a theatrical performance AND activity room (i.e. poker games). You're free to move about the venue after watching the initial performance. You don't know who is a character and who isn't, and it all ties together really well!!

While I'm sad that I don't have any pictures from the evening, it wouldn't have been the same had there been any hint of technology.

The Biz Times says it best: "the club's staff of 35 servers, bartenders and performers are all actors, strategically scattered throughout each of the club's rooms to bring the place to life through carefully crafted story lines of The Speakeasy. They include floozies and bootleggers, degenerate gamblers and war veterans troubled by the past."
author: Regina D.

description:
I have to urge you to experience this interactive theatre at least once. 
I enjoyed:
- The secretive element of it all, meeting at one place and given paper directions to the next, complete with pass codes
- Dressing up and trying to get as close to historically accurate
- Being transported for a night
-The front room performances (jokes, girls dancing, and the playing off the audience)
-being amidst dialogues between characters
- the little nook where you become purely an observer and see/hear the interactions between characters in their dressing room
- the last room that opens up to a bar, lounge complete with a singer and pianist.
-THE ACTORS were amazing. without a doubt.
Exploring: we opened what looked like a closet and crouched down to see that we could now enter "Joe's Clock Shop" abandoned and a secret we felt like we were the only ones that discovered it.

Some possible minor cons:
- The spaces were cramped, compared to the amount of people, we had squeeze by when transitioning from room to room. But again I liked that it was alive 
- The mixed drinks were not good. To put it simply. My two friends decided to be adventurous at first, but ended up nursing the wine i ordered because either it tasted like straight alcohol or was overly-sweetened. Stick to the wine
-The area is not the best at night, if you're leaving late, have a buddy with you and you'll feel more secure

Besides that, Id say have fun with it, I went in with near no expectations and was blown away. Dress up, and experience it, don't read too many reviews dont spoil it for yourself.
OUTFIT IDEAS
My Tips for ladies dressing up: Go Thrifting for a cheap boxy or dropwaisted dress with embellishments like beading, pearls etc. The size doesn't matter I got a dress way too large and it was perfectly fine, shapeless dresses are perfect. Nude tights are great, dance shoes or t-straps (I got some at a thrift store for $5. Cheap pearls (available at Michaels) Faux, or real! Fur coats.
I got an amazing long cigarette holder on amazon for $15. Probably my favorite purchase in the last month.
Makeup in a nutshell: vampy lips, smoky eyes, and pale skin. heres a helpful youtube tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P_iMr-yOUbo

Have fun!
author: Zoe C.

description:
I highly recommend this experience! It certainly isn't your average night out on the town. If you're looking for a unique date night or group event, this is a great idea! 

I suggest purchasing the casino chips, it's fun to play craps in the casino. 

Know you are free to move around on your own time and enjoy the night at your own pace. Look for the backstage dressing room of the casino, it's a hidden gem. 

Most people are dressed up in style of the 20's, if you decide to get all decked out, you'll fit right in.

This is an exceptional night out; I plan to go again!
author: c m.

description: This place is fantastic. Anyone and everyone should see this show at least once. Such a unique and engaging experience even for someone like myself who does not normally attend such performances. The Speakeasy is great for groups ( we had a group of 10), dates, and celebrations of all sorts. To top it all off the drinks are strong and readily available to order. Big thumbs up from this guy.
author: Chris T.

description: Amazing experience.  This show is very well done. Dressing up in the 20's era is always fun, but this takes it to another level. The venue is well done and really makes you feel like you stepped back in time. Having the play happening around you is such a different experience. I love also that you can gamble (although the amounts are small, it's more for the fun of it).  I highly recommend going there. We went there in a big group and it made it even better.
author: Yann L.

description: Wow. Such a cool event. The 1920s slang. The great singing. The costumes on the actors and on the patrons. You really can't tell who's who or what what or when is when. It is that immersive. We were so surprised when the raid came and we all got kicked out the back door ahead of the police. We had quite forgotten the night would end and we would be back in 2016. Great show. I want to go again
author: Cynthia S.

description: What a special evening we had at The Speakeasy. We dressed the part before stepping back in time. This is a class operation; signature drinks that relaxed us and got us in the mood, an interesting plot that makes us want to return to learn more, absolutely outstanding acting and an environment of the 20's with a bar, casino, cabaret which we could roam through with pleasure. It was a night extraordinaire !
author: Barbara H.

description: It was our 2nd visit and we enjoyed it even more this time. The effort and organization that goes into this performance is staggering.  The drinks are excellent as well.  I appreciated the addition of some snacks since our first visit.  We will be back.
author: Jennifer R.

description: Amazing performances, great settings, and excellent service.
author: S C.

description: I wasn't sure what to expect going in since a friend's coworker suggested the place. I'm glad I didn't know what to expect because that allowed me to enjoy the experience much more. My friends and I all dressed up in period attire and had a blast. I would definitely recommend this place as a fun night out!
author: Jennifer M.

description: My husband and I came to SF for our honeymoon. I have always wanted to go to a real speakeasy. A local told us about Speakeasy SF and we were thrilled with our experience. From the moment I began my ticket purchase to the end of the night, they really get into 1920s characters and they don't waiver. We had to get a password and meet a character in an alley for our tickets. From there they give you directions to the joint. We didn't pack any 20s regalia but they will hook you up as you walk in.  I wore a simple knit black dress and they gave me some beads and a feather headband thing.  It worked. You pick your "opening act" either drama, comedy, or spectacle.  My husband wanted the drama one. It was good but a little dry.  Next time we'll pick comedy or spectacle.   When the opening act is finished you are led to the "Palace" for the rest of your show. You feel like you are part of the show because some of the scenes are happening at the table next to you. It was like nothing we've ever experienced and we just loved it!
author: Heather E.

description: A little slow at first, but it truly builds. A true experience that you can't get the full entirety of in one sitting as things are happening simultaneously throughout the three different sections of the Speakeasy (cabaret, bar, and casino). You're not watching from a stage. You're in the middle of it and move through the rooms throughout the night. It combines period style entertainment with a bit of historical teachings. The drama builds around a surprisingly large cast of characters. Very well written and produced. Very talented actors and musicians. Have some fun and come in period style clothing.
author: Mark C.

description:
THIS IS THE BEE'S KNEES. And you should go.

The Speakeasy is an innovative theatre production cleverly disguised as a 1920's prohibition saloon, complete with flapper girls, gambling, police raids, and great, great singing, and even better acting. The experience runs from 7/8 pm (depending on your entry time) to exactly 11 pm; within those hours it's a choose-your-own-adventure philosophy where you wander throughout the space, lingering in whichever room you prefer (be it the cabaret, the casino hall, the dressing room perhaps), not knowing if the person next to you is another guest or an actor. You may find secret rooms, be privy to the latest gossip, witness brawls; but whatever you'll find, at the end of the night, you'll be fleeing from the cops.

Or, as my boyfriend David would describe it: "You see, Copper, sometimes you gotta find the perfect place to look at dames and molls, and get canned, corked, tanked, primed, scrooched, jazzed, zozzled, plastered, owled, embalmed, lit, potted, ossified or fried to the hat. What does that mean? It mean's to get drunk, sheik. And getting drunk at a gin mill like The Speakeasy, surrounded by those gams, listening to the music and enjoying a bit of the 1920's is the right way to spend your evening."

No photos allowed in the event, so take pics before and after. Period costumes not required, but strongly encouraged. They are sold out every night for the rest of March and April, but there are some availability in May and June yet! Groups of 15 get 15% off when purchased together.
author: Liuyin S.

description:
The Speakeasy was interesting and worth doing but here were my issues with it:
-The man guarding the door all night was rude and acted annoyed with everyone who didn't know what they were supposed to do...which was most of us.
-We were sat in the main room to start where they had an hour long "play" that had no plot. We had to sit there watching the actors all around us and we couldn't move. I hadn't realized that it would be 90% show.
-The cocktail menu was just a brief summary of ingredients, so I got a drink with Campari, even though I hate Campari.
-The guests costumes were better than the actors.
-The actors weren't all that good.
-The gambling was so cramped and busy that it was very hard to partake. 
-I got yelled at when I wandered around.

Here's what I liked:
-Most guests were dressed up. 
-The comedians were funny.
-The 5 minutes of dancing was awesome.
author: Kaya C.

description: This was an incredible show! It exceed my expectations and I was really blown away by the fun, professional and entertaining experience!! I will go again since there is so much I didn't see! Make sure to dress in period 1920 clothes - think Great Gatsby!
author: Chris W.

description: Loved it!!  Worth every penny and will  definately bring more friends to experience this amazing event!!
author: Teresa B.

description: Spectacular.  A must see and truly memorable experience.   Well done from start to finish.  The production quality, historical context and story flow is both subtle and engaging.
author: Stephen P.

description: A great way to spend an evening. I had no idea what to expect. It is basically several story lines that happen around you and a huge cast of embedded characters coming and going from each room. You don't really participate. The plot line is set and you observe. People really dress up for this, which makes it fun and the time goes by quickly. We started in the Cabaret  and the show was good! They don't repeat anything so there's always something to see. Next time I want to start in the Bar. The Casino is also fun but note that you can't use your winnings for anything it's just for fun. The drinks are good but a little pricey, but given the large cast and the musicians and sets it's an expensive production.  To save money, don't reserve a table in the Cabaret or bar, you can see fine from anywhere in the room.
author: Priscilla C.

description: Epic immersive experience. Really transports you to a different world. Their attention to detail is immaculate. Perfect date spot or place to go out with some friends!
author: Khaled N.

description: What an amazing night!! I'd never been to an immersive theater performance before and the Speakeasy did not disappoint - I loved every second!! It was so fun following characters, going from room to room checking out different scenes and stories, getting to follow so many different plots. The actors and sets were all incredible - I really felt like we stepped back in time to the 20s! You can play blackjack in the casino, watch a show in the Cabaret, drink and sing along to the piano player in the bar, peak in on the actors in the (fake) dressing room or bosses office... it's really all so incredible!  I want to go back 10 more times so I can see parts I missed!  Such a fun night, I highly recommend The Speakeasy SF!!!
author: Andria K.

description:
Fantastic experience!! I'd been to immersive theatres in London, and was surprised to discover that San Francisco has one of its own, and had been around since 2015 (although this is their new, renovated location from the tenderloin). 

We went in not knowing what to expect, but dressed up in period attire because that always makes it more fun! The shows were spectacular, the cabaret was easily the most entertaining portion (and where we spent most of our time sipping period cocktails). The scenes in the casino and bar were sometimes hard to follow, but it adds to the overarching storyline so it helps to move around! 

I didn't realise until we left when we ran into an actor outside that we had missed 2 rooms completely... And not to give anything away, but check those hidden doors, you never know!
author: Vivien O.

description: Absolutely amazing. The amount of Production is insane. It's a 3 hour play. Everyone stayed in character, and are tremendously talent actors/Actresses. It's $110 Per Person and It was wroth EVERY penny! Go GO GO support the Actors/Producers/Band that are part of this experience!
author: Greg B.

description: I first went in it's former location at Joe's Clock Shop, actually I went twice because I loved it so much and told so many friends about the show. I also went when you were just throwing parties, while building out your new space. Unfortunately for me when I returned for your grand reopening giddy for the same great experience in a bigger space I was met with BLACK FACE. I legitimately feel as if you just slapped that in there, you didn't need it before so why now? I won't be returning to this and I have told everyone that I cheered to about this that it's not worth their money or their time. Please don't bother telling about your motivation and how you're trying to keep it historically accurate. You created an entertainment piece that glorifies it more than it condemns it. There isn't time for dialogue with those who are experiencing it so what impact do you think this will really have, just that you show it and that's it? Again, you didn't need it before so why now?
author: David S.

description: Our party of six had a great time at this immersive theatre experience.  It's not cheap, but it's a lot of fun, and the combination of the different rooms--cabaret, bar, casino--yields fun and interesting scenes from the cast.  Give it a try!
author: Louis T.

description: This show was NOT worth the money. The overall decoration and costumes and arrangement is nice. But there is no show.  It is just dialogue, no conflict, no story, no intrigue, no mystery.  Just three rooms with very slow moving activities.  We went on a Sunday evening and there were very few people so maybe that contributed to thew lack of energy. But in the past, I have had interaction in an interactive show. Not a single person spoke to my girlfriend the entire night. I did have some participation but it was silly and uninteresting.  If they spent half as much time working on the show as they spend on the entrance, the secrecy of the location and the decorations then it would be better.
author: Z A.

description: On the plus side, the interior design was excellent, the performers were good enough, and they seemed to be pretty well organized - producing/directing/stage managing that many areas is quite an accomplishment.  The 2 main problems for me were being trapped in the building (on purpose) at the end of the night and not getting enough of any storyline to understand anything by the end of the night.  (And why was I given a flower to wear?  Was I suppose to be at the show by a certain time?  How would I know the time - no watches, phones of course, and I didn't notice any clocks in the house). I won't give examples so as not to ruin anything for anyone else, but I didn't get enough of ANY storyl ine to understand anything of what happened by the end of the night (and I was there at the very very beginning).  It would have been better if there was some type of expected rotations through the space to get a base of information, then allow for random wandering.  And if you don't know about the secret spaces you miss out.  Then at the end of the night I wanted to leave the theatre area but wasn't allowed, was told "there was an accident to clean up".  When we got BS/no answers of why we couldn't exit from either direction I asked if this was part of the schtick or please tell me why I can't leave the building.  Eventually a lead/manager of some sort came by and asked if I could just wait a few minutes - at this point I felt trapped and said no, I wanted to leave right then. They did let me out only to find out they were wrapping up the evening and letting people out in groups.  Why didn't they just say so?  The double cherry on top is that I set up my bar tab before their noted time (got a confirmation it worked) then got there and they didn't have my "charging wooden nickel" - okay, things happen so I give them my credit card then, all seems to go well for that evening's charges then 2 days later I get a "the card didn't go through, click here to pay" message.  Ah jeez, okay (why didn't they check the run that night - I'm no where near the limit and had other cards too) but (make it triple cherry on top) their online payment system wants to keep my account open and I have to go somewhere else to deactivate it.  What?!?  Final tip - don't go with a large group, you can't stick together, you don't have a shared experience and some people get left behind - literally - all alone not knowing where anyone went.  (oh, and I'm never a fan of automatic tipping - 18% - what if the service was terrible and not deserving?)
author: JJ S.

description: I went to my first Speakeasy SF performance a few years ago in their old space by the civic center and was completely enchanted. I was listening to 1920s jazz for weeks afterward to transport me back. Thrilled to report that this new show is bigger and better than ever. I love the amount of energy this team has poured into trying to create as authentic an experience as they can; there are so many beautiful details to take in from the music (their live band is so talented) dialogue to the costumes and the sets, even down to creating authentic drinks from the era. The entire cast offers delightful performances and I can't wait to bring all my friends with me when I come back again and again to try to experience each storyline in its entirety. A few familiar characters are back as well as new ones, and the cabaret acts are so much fun (especially if you're lucky enough to catch a certain special dance party that invites audience participation). Almost dizzying how much is happening at once and the orchestration they manage to pull off is an impressive feat. I also can't stress enough how refreshing it is to be in a space where people aren't on their cell phones! I left mine at home since I live in the neighborhood and it was so nice to just be fully present and take in the show without seeing everyone around me trying to take pictures or scrolling on their cellphones. If you went to their last show then you won't be surprised at how the night ends. If you didn't you're in for a fun surprise :)
author: Kim H.

description:
Went to the show on 5/6/14. Great experience. Loved every minute.

To warn: my companions had been to Sleep No More in NYC, and were expecting The Speakeasy to be a bit more like that. From what I hear, this is on a much smaller scale. To me that's a good thing: you'll see more of the show instead of coming away knowing that you missed 90% of it. In fact, I could have stayed in the cabaret room the whole night and been totally content.

Go while you still can! And be sure to get in costume.
author: Mike D.

description:
This show was amazing! You leave feeling like you were part of the show itself and actually learning a lot about the 1920s era. It is a very unique and fantastic experience and everyone on the team played their roles SO WELL. Very impressed with everyones performance and being able to play their parts for a good three hours! It must be so hard to do when the circumstances and people around you are different every night. All the actors and actresses were perfect for their roles and you really become immersed in each character's emotions and story lines.
I wouldn't recommend going to the show on a first date since there are so many things happening but with a small group of friends, it's a delightful experience.
Definitely dress up in the 1920s era- ladies, wear something flapper girl-ish (head-bands, feathers, vintage dresses, and red lipstick) and men shouldn't be afraid to wear a suit, a bow tie, and even a bowler hat. It definitely enhances the overal experience of the night for everyone there. Make sure to be on time and head over as soon as you can so you can get a seat to watch the first third of the show.
You could order drinks throughout the night and there were also non-alcoholic drinks like ginger beer and sarsaparilla. Plus, there was a room where you could play Blackjack and Craps. You were given a coin before entering the building and you could exchange it for a purple bag of tokens to play. It was great being able to watch the show and take a break and play a few light-hearted games (not for real money).
There are a lot of things happening around you and the whole time you should be whispering and not talking very loud at all- otherwise, you will be hushed.
The songs were all great and by the end of the night, everyone was singing along to the last number. Again, the team is talented and very engaging and I would highly recommend this show to anyone.
author: Grace L.

description:
I've visited "Joe's Clock Shop" twice and had an enjoyable experience each time. Both visits were (slightly) different, and I picked up on much more of the story plot the second time around. However, it's an entirely different vibe and atmosphere than NYC's Sleep No More. Aside from following actors around (in a much more compact space) there is no comparison really. Don't expect the same type of experience as Sleep No More.

The storyline throughout the night is a bit, err-uhh... mehh. I guess it's subjective, but I'll speak on the positives that was enjoyed by all in our group:

A+ for creating an excellent "speakeasy atmosphere" paired with everyone dressed to the nine's. The dress code is taken very serious.
B+ for the gambling area (even though it's not real money and the dealers lack personality--still fun).
A- for the crazy-strong drinks. They are humorous when you ask what type of booze/wine/beer is actually in your drink. (Mystery never solved and that's A-ok).
B for the actors/actresses interacting with you and making you feel part of the story. My second time around I was approached a lot and felt much more a part of the story than the first time.
A+ for the effort in offering a unique San Francisco experience that is fun to attend with a group of friends.

Overall the storyline can be a bit agitating and dark at points... and some of the singing/dancing/choreography could be polished up a notch, but overall  it's definitely worth checking out and can be as fun as you make it.
author: DJ P.

description: This is an absolute San Francisco gem. Many people don't even know this place exists, but once you are inside, you'll never forget it. The Speakeasy is Alive. It will unfold before your eyes in ways you can never expect. I have been 6 times now and each time had a completely different experience. The theater is worked into the event so seamlessly that a scene will begin unfolding around you and you won't even notice until you are right in the middle of it. You can sit back and soak it in - or be adventurous and explore from room to room to see what is going on behind the scenes. A truly special experience.
author: Ben Y.

description:
By far one of the experiences I've had in SF. I highly highly recommend if you are on the fence (yes, it's pricey, but its well beyond worth it)

A couple suggestions to maximize your experience 

1. Dress up in period outfits. It makes the experience even better and adds to the fun of not being able to tell who's an actor and who's a guest 

2. Be strategic about your time. Don't spend all your time in one room. The people who maximized their experiences chose a character and followed them throughout the space. This enables you to view their storyline in all the hidden parts of the space. Once that storyline gets boring, move on to the next character 

3. Shed your inhibitions. Interact with the actors (when they interact with you) and really buy into the time period setting. You won't do this many times in a lifetime.
author: Meghana D.

description: Such an amazing night. Totally immersed in the whacky world of a 1923 speakeasy with a cabaret, a bar, a casino and so many plots/characters to follow that we will definitely go again. Don't miss some of the hidden fun, like the view of the dressing room and the sliding bookcase pass through from the bar to the casino!
author: Michael L.

description: I great time with friend getting all dressed up and time traveling to the '20's.  You really experience what a speak easy would be like.  The venue is very authentic, the costumes are great and the characters give it their all.  There is a great older character, a salesman, in the bar that is very funny in his crass demeanor (we saw him in the beginning of our journey).  I also loved Viola the main singer and LOVED Eddie the Emcee.  It was interesting to see contrasting characters like the couple looking for a chorus girl who knew their son.  I loved the backstage set and watching those scenes between the chorus girls.  The main cabaret and band was fantastic too!  All and all I would definitely go back again to see what's going on with the other scenes.  It's a unique theater experience!
author: Susan A.

description:
This was amazing. I have a background in immersive theater (I even interned on Sleep No More, which many people reference in comparison) and all of my expectations were met or exceeded, I spent the evening in a magical, vibrant, interesting, fun, wonderland of history. Of course the scale is not as large as some productions, but I thought 3 main rooms, plus a few smaller areas to explore, were done to perfection, appropriate for a speakeasy theme, and kept us busy all night. You could easily sit in just the cabaret all night and have a great time.
A few thing I wish I would have known:
-Don't bother to reserve a table, unless you have a big group. We reserved a table for part 1 and didn't even get sat in the seats we reserved (better ones actually), plus every time we came back to the cabaret there were plenty of seats and no one stopping us from sitting anywhere we wished. 
-Also, I have no idea how they distinguish between parts 1, 2 and 3, or how someone with a reserved table for parts 2 or 3 would know when their reservations begin. We just eventually left the cabaret when there was a pause and we were ready to explore more
-Get casino chips, it really is fun to play and 1 set for 10$ will do it. it's a nice pause if you get tired of watching the action. Scenes do happen and interrupt the game, but we found plenty of time to gamble.
-I needed to make dinner reservations in advance but wanted them to be walkable--not knowing the location made that hard. So let me just say it's near the Colombus hub of North Beach 

I appreciated the touches of no real money, no phones/cameras, and period-appropriate drinks. And everyone really dressed up! Kudos to the audience! It was fun not to know who was a character or not. There isn't much in the way of character interaction though. Shout out to Velma, the MC and Mac the bartender for being my favorite characters. 

A few cons, mostly that other people have mentioned:
-Entry. It's true, there's just a bunch of dressed up people waiting to talk to the guy and hearing the rules multiple times until it's their turn. However the effect of going from a dinghy alleyway staircase into a club was awesome!
-The plot. I have NO idea what happens in this story. it's not necessary to have a good time, heck, maybe there isn't even an overarching plot--but I thought we were really ambitious in traversing the rooms and we only saw fragments of people's stories and were never aware of how most tied together. It sounds like some people in these reviews saw too much plot and that it was negative.
-Drink service was pretty slow. We didn't get the free drinks everyone else entering in the cabaret got, and it took 15-20 minutes to get my first drink from the server. At the bar, there's a good chance the bartender is acting in a scene and unable to serve you. it got better throughout the night, maybe as they got through an initial rush? 

A few cons other people have mentioned which I don't think are valid:
-This is NOT Sleep no more and you shouldn't expect it to be. Mostly it's much smaller, but among other differences, set interaction is not really a part of this show.
-The website is very clear about speaking "easy" (not talking) being one of the rules. You should expect to be watching more than partying/talking.
author: Eve B.

description:
I rarely write reviews, but this was so bad, that I felt I needed to give feedback to the show - and it wasn't bad for a lack of effort from the cast and crew. I really believe everyone was working hard and doing their best. But it was still a terrible experience.
We went to the Speakeasy on 9/29 for my birthday. In addition to tickets, we purchased table reservations for the cabaret and casino chips. I wish we could get our money back, as we literally left well before the show ended. None of us felt there was anything to stay for (plus, it was past 11:30pm and still not over?!). Not interesting, not interactive, not organized. It was a waste of $700+ for my family to go and a poor birthday experience. I would definitely not recommend this to anyone!

Pros:
- Costumes - fun to see everyone dressed up and definitely in the spirit of the event. 
- Check-in - It was a little crowded, but I asked for an earlier time and so I think we had no issues. Our clue was to check in with a person holding a red umbrella. The umbrella was a bit hidden but really, that was fine and continued to be fun.
- Environment/Staging - the space is actually done amazingly well and you really do feel like you're in the 20s. Kudos to the set design team and props team. 
- Casino - the casino was probably the most fun for our group, but don't bother buying chips ahead of time.

Cons:
- Purchasing process - I've never been to a show like this and was very confused about how it works. You could get reservations, but then you could wander around. There was nothing to really help a newbie. 
- Show - The show was horrible and IMPOSSIBLY hard to follow. It was also incredibly dark and disturbing. I agree with someone else's comments about expecting a fun entertaining evening and getting a dark, disturbing show. The impression first given when purchasing tickets (knock and give a password) and checking-in (find xyz) and even dressing up give the expectation that this is a fun, roaring 20s kind of show. This isn't the type of set up I would expect for such a dark show. I was expecting fun murder mystery type show and I got something more akin to Schindler's List. This was not the birthday memory I wanted!
- Organization - it was impossible to tell when one act ended and another one began. We started in the bar and had reservations for act 2 in the cabaret. At one point in time, there was a long pause in the bar and a number of people moved from one location to another. So we thought the act had changed. Considering we purchased reservations in advance at $10 per person, we figured that was the end of the act and we should go to the next room. We arrived in the cabaret and had to wait to be seated - I'm still not sure if it was because we switched rooms too soon or if our table was taken by other guests who just moved from room to room or didn't leave from the previous act. The lack of transition for acts was an issue the entire evening. It wouldn't have been a big deal if we were told to just explore, but by setting up the expectation of acts during the purchasing process and PAYING for the cabaret tables and casino chips, we expected to go to different locations at different times.
- Service/Drinks - drinks were strong, but not very good. And the service was poor. We were waiting constantly for a waiter and even after ordering, our drinks took too long. The built in 18% gratuity is ridiculous, especially for such poor service. We also all felt there should have been some kind of food served - even snacks.
Bathrooms - I think there was only one set of bathrooms. Thankfully, I hit the restroom when there were no crowds.
author: Lisa V.

description:
My friends and I were VERY surprised by the atmosphere, high production value and character of The Speakeasy.  Imagine living in the 1920's during prohibition and being one of the lucky few to know someone who knows someone who can get you into a place to drink illegal alcohol, gamble and see some sexy showgirls. I was confused at first, but then I just got it.  Walk around and explore.  There are side conversations, hidden rooms, drama between the characters, etc.

The only thing that ruined the experience was some of the guests didn't dress up in period clothing.  There were a couple people in t-shirts and jeans, one guy wore a polo shirt, another had a nice suit, but wore sneakers.  Not good.  If you go, wear 1920's attire. 

Come see it, you will not be disappointed.
author: Michael Y.

description: The scale of this thing is incredibly impressive. I was in awe of the talent and sheer number of actors and storylines going on simultaneously. I've done Sleep No More in NYC and this is right up there with that in terms of unique entertainment experiences, but I have to give The Speakeasy the edge in that the storylines are more relatable and the scenery more lively and fun (it's a friggin' speakeasy). Of all the events and things to do in SF, this is one of the best. It's going to be a massive hit. My advice: don't skip out on getting dressed up. One of the fun parts for me was not knowing who was in the show and who was a spectator. Most people were really into and dressed the part, but a few people clearly didn't know what they were in for and stuck out. Not a big deal, but I definitely think it's more fun when you get into it. There are bars and servers inside so grab a few cocktails and hang out in the cabaret and enjoy the show.
author: Jesse G.

description:
A true fantasy, 
Transported to the twenties, 
Best night of the year. 

(GO SEE IT NOW!!!!!0
author: Brian J.

description: This show is AMAZING! If your looking for a few hour get away or just want to go back to the 20s this is the place. The acting makes you feel like you're really there! Just make sure to "speakeasy".
author: Ariel M.

description:
We didn't know what to expect and were blown away by a professionalism that showed in an ability of the group to keep us in a total suspense throughout the evening. At certain point i was even questioning if my friends were involved in acting :)
Definitely recommend to wear something that represents the time period (easy to do), you would appreciate it when you get there. Almost everyone was dressed up. You will feel out of place if you are wearing jeans and sweatshirt. Go for it, you will have fun!
author: Galina F.

description: It is like taking a step back in time to the 1920's. Absolutely incredible experience. From dressing up in an era appropriate cocktail dress to the secrecy of the location to the outstanding performances and attention to detail. I can't wait to go again and again and again.
author: Alexis C.

description:
My actress daughter and I went to last night's show.  She had seen "Sleep No More" in NYC and found similarities, although Speakeasy's venue is considerably more compact. The experience was not as I had expected, and certainly not your usual SF theater evening.  To fully enjoy your show, and I do recommend that you go, follow the instructions carefully.  Dress as requested but don't feel you have to over-do it.  You want to be part of the staging.  Do explore the various venues as the many story lines play out across the rooms.  If you take a liking to one in particular, follow the actors.  I won't say more about the show itself as it would spoil the discovery that is so much a part of the evening.  Be prepared for drama, comedy, singing, dancing, decent drinks, and great fun.

The show runs long and the rooms are warm, but don't let that keep you from the after-show party.  The group is talented, delightful, interesting, and engaging. Speakeasy has been extended which is an indication of the quality of the production and the fun you will have.
author: Phil S.

description:
This is like no other theater experience I've ever had.  Very, very cool.

I don't want to give too much away, but be prepared to be thoroughly entertained in a time machine with a bunch of other theater-goers.

Do dress as they recommend (this really will enhance the experience for everyone).
Do be prompt.
Do order one of their suggested cocktails.
Do "gamble".
Do explore ALL the rooms of the experience.
Do note some parallels with some of today's social issues.
Do chat a few people up.
Do speak easy.

Don't expect to experience the exact same story as a friend who has already gone or even someone else who is there the same night as you.  For me, it was about the experience more than the story.

I think this will sell out quickly once word gets around so my advice is to snap up tickets quickly.  I'll be going again and taking some friend with me.
author: John D.

description:
We Attended the second day showing for the performance of The Speakeasy at the Box Car Theatre.

It was a wonderful Christmas gift from my wife.  The performance is very interactive and unique in that it draws the audience into the illicit behavior of the 1920 era's backroom saloons (think of Great Gatsby etc).

You will be notified via text to arrive at a certain place and time with a secret password.  Once you find your contact at that location you exchange information and given a location and another password to enter the establishment.

This is where the fun begins.

The outside of the place has something to be desired of but that is part of the whole appeal.  You knock on the door and give the person the password to enter.  Once inside the "performances" take place in several locations.  The main "stage" has a combination of singing and dancing, as well as, vaudeville acts from that era.  The second part of the location contains a "hidden" casino with a roulette, craps, and blackjack tables.  The back of the place has a small room which you can view events happening in the changing room and a bar/performance/sitting area.

Performers will be interacting in front and all around you.  It's a wonderful idea and concept because you become immersed in the various story lines.

We reserved a table in the front and watched a show with some wonderful singing, dance numbers, and comedy routines.  You may not recognize most of the songs from that time but as the night progresses you will eventually find a few nuggets that you will easily recall hearing from an old movie or television show.   I enjoyed listening to all of them and especially enjoyed the rendition of "We have no Banana's Today."  I don't believe you could even create or sing that song nowadays as it would offend just about the whole ethnic makeup of SF but the tongue and cheek performance was absolutely marvelous!

We then moved to the back where we went to the "casino" room.  I literally blew everything on black and when the ball landed on red we made our way out to the back room.  The backroom contains a small stage with a piano, bar, and sitting room.  In the sitting room actors will be having conversations with each other and making performances on the small stage.  This is happening the same time performances are occurring in the front of the place on the main stage.

Keep in mind that so much is happening around you that you can not possibly see and experience everything.  That's part of the appeal of the show is that each person sees things differently and not everybody catches the whole storyline.  I will not give too much away other than it was a wonderful evening and something I would highly recommend to others.  Several people left before the ending number but I recommend to stay to the last minute as it is a fun closing and if you are lucky enough to get invited to the "after party" to attend. 

I would suggest coming to the show in period attire as it helps create the mood of what you are about to see and experience.  The performance is about your experience in one night at an actual speakeasy.  It is presented in a way that draws you into that era of dancing girls, booze and all.
author: Johnny V.

description:
You will be escorted into an area that is quite small, with most of the tables on the first floor reserved for performers.  If you can't find a seat on the first floor there is a claustrophobic second floor mezzanine where you need to duck to avoid the ductwork.  

The first 1/3 of the show takes place on a stage where the Emcee and his side-kick tell corny jokes and sing typical 20's songs.  There are singing, dancing flappers and other shenanigans, like an unfathomably bad magician.  My husband was groaning so loudly during the show that I suggested it might be annoying to those around him.  He said he couldn't take the show one minute longer, so I stayed with 2 other friends.  Maybe this is authentic Speakeasy fare, but not entertaining to any of us.

During the second 1/3 of the evening, you are allowed to move into another area with 3 very small rooms where you can gamble at one of three tables:  roulette, blackjack and craps.  Of course, even if you win you don't really make any money because you turn in your chips at the end of the night.  As the bouncer/doorman told me, "you are on the edge of reality".  

During the final 1/3 of the show another room is opened where there's a bar and piano player.  Then ensues a little drama about a hysterical woman chasing her husband around the Speakeasy because he has brought their 11-year old daughter there and spent all his money on drinking and gambling.  Hackneyed subject.  Then many Depression era songs, like "Once I Had a Railroad", a fast-forward on the lives of the characters, i.e. "he never saw his wife and child again", "102 and living in a retirement community", etc.  

You aren't supposed to speak above a whisper, which in general inhibits conversation.  They are ending the show on June 21.  I was very disappointed because I read the great reviews, many of which were probably written by the performers.

One more thing, upon exiting the "Speakeasy" you will find yourself in the midst of the Tenderloin where most will not feel safe waiting for a taxi.  It took us about 15 minutes to get a cab at 10:15, during which time we were anxious about the crowds of locals congregating on corners.
author: Rene R.

description:
Such a unique, amazing, exciting experience.  This was one of the best shows/parties I have been to! Make sure to reserve a cabaret table, and afterhours passes to afterparty.  Also, make sure to dress 1920's attire; you'll feel silly if you don't!  

I can't wait to go back again to see more of things I may have missed the first time around! SO MUCH FUN!
author: Suzanna F.

description: We went to the Speakeasy last night and found it fully delightful.  It was impressive to see how much was going on all around us and sometimes it was difficult to tell whether we were with actors or other guests, except we remembered that guests were not supposed to converse, so anyone who speaks to you is one of the performers.  They try to involve you in the goings-on very cleverly, and that makes it a lot of fun, indeed.  So many talented performers!  What a great time to play pretend all evening and escape to another world!  Highly recommended to everyone willing to imagine and pretend!  If you go, do try to dress more or less like the period, as that helps to draw you into the atmosphere.
author: Lydia S.

description:
It was an amazing event. 

I could tell that my wife was so swept away by everything going on around her that she wanted to be a part of the show. Which is great, because the guests are a part of the show. Once you show up, your energy helps build everything around you. 

Remember to move around and see everything you can. I went with a friend who has been before and she was blown away because she saw a completely different show simply by walking in a different door then the last time.
author: John V.

description:
My girlfriend and I went last night and we had a blast. I don't want to give anything away, but it really was an immersive experience, even starting when you first contact them. So many bits of theater going on all around that I think I'll need to go back to catch all the little story lines. 

My only (minor) complaint is that several other patrons didn't seem to understand what the show was about and carried on (loudly) like they were in a regular bar. So if you go, remember to speak *easy*!

Still I highly recommend it. It's really different from anything I've seen before.
author: Robert L.

description: SO COOOOOOOOL!! From start to finish, I couldn't see it all and can't wait to go back and see more. Love being thrust into a different time period, and loved the excitement of finding the right dress, shoes, hair, and being involved in my own way. I also loved keeping my date in the dark and he had no idea what to expect and was so pleasantly surprised. Wish it was a permanent thing.
author: Beth A.

description: Awesome experience!  I loved all the "hidden" rooms and the excitement of trying to find out what or who was around the corner.  The music was great and the entertainers were top-notch!  We plan on coming back to see it again!
author: Jenny F.

description: Incredible production values, unreal immersion, great drinks, fun games... I'll be back again and again.
author: Dave W.

description:
So so awesome! You truly feel transported to another time, and my husband and I really lost track of the time. There was so much to discover on set, let alone the amazingly creative and deep characters running around it. We could easily go back and experience something totally new!

Recommend it!
author: Jeff L.

description:
Fantastic cocktails and impeccable service, though the lass and I may have gotten a little carried away at the craps table. Top-notch entertainment; the piano player and the Tic Toc band seemed to know all my favorite current hit songs and even played a few oldies from as far back as a couple years ago (1918 or so?).

Great place for crowd-watching, too. And I still can't stop dreaming about those dancing girls - a bunch of regular hot tomatoes!

Sure, there was a little drama around the club, fights breakin out here & there, and after a few drinks I swear I experienced a prophetic vision of the future -- but hey, it was a Friday night; what guy on a toot doesn't see a little action?

Bottom line: dress in your fines, follow the rules, explore a lot but keep your nose down (and your voice down!) and you'll have a grand ol' time just being a fly on the wall.

Just promise me you won't tell the wife (or the Treasury Department!) why my pocketwatch seems to be in need of such frequent repair.
author: myrrh l.

description:
What a great show - it's a very unique experience. The decor and theming is top-notch, they've done a terrific job with it. 

Definitely dress up, many in the audience had the 1920s look and it added to the ambiance (and made it hard to tell the actors from the audience at times, which adds to the immersive nature of the performance). 

It would be a fun place to hang out in simply to hang out in, but the fact that a show is unfolding around you really kicks it up a notch. 

It may be impossible to see the resolution of  every storyline in a single evening as it takes place in different rooms and you can follow actors or stay put, or do a little of both. On the other hand, it certainly makes me want to go back and see it again at some point. 

Tip: Choose an early entry time.
author: Ed M.

description: The SpeakEasy was one of the most unique experiences that I've had in a long time! It's the closest thing that you'll get to getting into a time machine and getting transported back in time.  The space is an incredible re-creation of what a 1930's Speakeasy might have been like.  The attention to detail is astounding-- to the point where I truly felt "immersed" in the underground belly of Prohibition-era San Francisco. Perhaps most importantly, you are pulled into a world of characters--mob bosses, dancers, writers and just "everyday" 1920's people.   Because most of the guests are dressed in period costume, it's never entirely clear who is part of the cast, and who is not. That adds to the mystery. If you want to have a completely immersive experience of going back to 1923--and experience great music/dance entertainment, a bit of gambling excitement, great drinks and thought-provoking historical storylines....or just have an evening full of surprises and fun, The SpeakEasy is highly recommended!  We can't wait to go again!
author: Hugh G.

description:
Our party of four came with high expectations, as this experience was highly recommended by a close friend. Couple that with the mostly great reviews on yelp, and we were excited!  We dressed in period clothing and we looked fantastic. :-)

Our show time was 9:00pm. The best part of the whole evening was the fun of tracking down the man with the yellow umbrella and giving our password. We were the first in our group to check in, promptly at 9pm as directed. We then proceeded to wait nearly 30 minutes in an alley with no direction. Finally, someone came by and said "What? You gonna sit out here all night?!"  When he realized no one had given us any direction, he was embarassed. 

Here's our synopsis:
- Don't buy the 9pm tickets. At that hour, they have you enter through an alley instead of the clock shop. I think it would have been much more authentic had we entered through the clock shop.
- The drinks are beyond horrible, sans the Guinness, unless you love whiskey. Had they simply had a better bar menu, we might've been able to stomach the rest of the evening. 
- The acting was at high school level, which got annoying quickly
- There was no real plot to follow, so it never really captured our attention/interest
- The room with the gambling was so tiny and so crowded, it wasn't even possible to walk inside let alone pull up to a table. 

Overall, it was a waste of our money and time. We ended up walking out of the show after about an hour and a half ...
author: Sheri G.

description:
Whoa, whoa, whoa. I dunno what's going on here; all these people talking about drinking and gambling and fast women have got it wrong. This is Joe's Clock Shop, and as far as I know Joe makes and repairs fine clocks, nothing more. He fixed up my old pocketwatch just last night. Joe happens to be a pal of mine and I can't let folks go around besmirching his good name like this.

It's true you don't see many clock shops that stay open all night, but that just proves what a dedicated businessman Joe is. And it's true you see a lot of stylishly dressed people coming in and out of his establishment in the wee hours, but that's just because he attracts a high-class clientele. Some of the neighbors have complained about about noise and music, but I ask you, is it a crime if a working man plays  some music to pass the time? 

Now I've also heard that there's a lot of rowdy behavior that tends to happen in this neighborhood, and there are rumors of some illegal gin-dealing and gambling and what have you. It wouldn't surprise me if you could stumble on some kind of blind tiger joint if you asked the right people. But I wouldn't know anything about all that. And I'm sure Joe doesn't either.

*
*
*
*
*
*

...all right, fun times aside, maybe you're wondering why I'm giving this gig "only" three stars when most other folks here are opting for five-star raves. Well, I was as excited to visit Black Box's little experiment as anyone. And, all told, I would recommend that anyone who thinks it sounds like fun ought to look into it. But at the same time, I can't pretend that this neat idea doesn't have a troubled execution.

To get in you've got to meet up with an informant a few blocks away, who gives you directions after you give him the password, provided to you ahead of time. Sounds fun, right? A great way to get everyone in the spirit of things. We were told to show up at the prescribed spot at "exactly" ten till the hour and to wait until the coast was clear before approaching. I assumed this was to prevent a line from forming and spoiling the illusion. Well, apparently it didn't work because there was a huge, milling crowd of people very obviously dressed for the show. It took quite a while before the tipster was available, and when I gamely played along and gave him the password he snapped at us, telling us he was busy and would take care of us shortly. So now I felt like an asshole, and the fun atmosphere of the gimmick was spoiled a bit. 

We ended up waiting around until everyone else had gone (I certainly wasn't going to bother him again, and even if I had what would I say? I'd have felt like a dick giving him the password a second time). Matter of fact, our assigned informant never did get back to us, and eventually one of the other guys noticed we'd been left hanging and took pity on us. He helped us out, but to be honest he was rather terse and snippy too. I couldn't tell if these guys were playing some kind of role or if they were just genuinely short-tempered, but it was an uncomfortable way to start the evening.

The clock shop thing is a nice setup and the interior of the place looks pretty good. I'd love to just hang around the set for a while if I had the opportunity. But right away we ran into another problem: They're very particular that you try not to talk or disrupt the show as it goes on, which makes sense. But there aren't nearly enough seats in the bar to accommodate all the of the actors and the audience, and if you're not lucky enough to snag one you're left just kind of hanging out awkwardly around the perimeter. No matter where you go you're bound to be in somebody's way. And here's the thing: There was no one we could ask where to go or what to do. We didn't dare talk to the actors and the few non-performer staffers were pretty busy.

At times I would want to move around to follow certain characters, but there was simply no space. There are several  rooms behind the bar that audience members are free to explore, but it's not immediately obvious where you're allowed to go and no way to tell who you're allowed to ask. For the record, the cast members and staffers were all very polite on the rare occasions they did acknowledge us. Only the guys outside were jerks. But if the audience can't have carte blanche to get in on the action then maybe it's best to assign them to their own designated section. That's how the backroom cabaret works, and it's noticeably more comfortable both for the audience and the performers.

Now, there's plenty of fun to be hard here too. It's hard to talk about the good stuff because that would mean spoiling the nuances, but I echo my previous statement that anyone who likes the sound of it should certainly explore it while it lasts. But I also feel obligated to point out that, while I considered going a second time to catch a few things I missed last night, the cagey attitude that hangs over the whole things will probably keep me away.
author: Tam Lin J.

description:
Fabulous fun! Granted this was my first interactive theater experience so I do not have a comparison. Therefore, everything exceeded my expectations! From the singing, the drama, strong drinks and the acting, you will be constantly entertained and not disappointed. By the way, come in costume or else feel like a dud!

The only downside was how crowded and hot it could become and that you couldn't cash your chips in like a real casino ;P.

My group bought our tickets separately and thus had instructions to enter the Clock Shop from different areas. If you want to stick together from the beginning, purchase your tickets in one batch. Otherwise have fun comparing and piecing together notes and stories throughout the night!
author: Sophia T.

description:
The wife and I went last night, as a result of a very nice present from her.  Despite the nice thought, this experience could have been MUCH better.

Let's take it from the top . . . 
- There's this whole, secret meeting process with passwords, etc that totally breaks down once you're just standing in a line behind other people waiting to say the same secret password.
- The performers are OK (the talent level of a high school play) but there's no "story" being told so it's just flat.  They also don't interact with the audience.
- I hope this doesn't happen to you but, while we're watching the performers, which we paid for, there was a woman who was practicing all the dance moves right next to us.  She was probably an understudy but it was very distracting to the patrons.  Tip: Rehearse your performance on your OWN time, not in front of the patrons.
- They have a selection of proprietary drinks but you can't read the menus in the dark.  The servers do their best to try and explain but its all very inefficient.
- The production just gets weird when the abandoned "wife" wanders around looking for her husband and daughter.  That was creepy.
- After the "show", they move everyone to the "casino" where it gets hot very quickly.  The dealers have stilted personalities and have to take off their shoes to count to 20.
- As we were leaving, I had to make a point of asking to see my drink tab.  I don't know about you but it makes me uncomfortable that a place just takes a credit card swipe and expects you to walk out and be surprised.  It was $23.50 for two cocktails (including the tip) so that wasn't bad.

Bottom line, we would not recommend nor repeat.  This could be a much better experience if someone thought this through a little more thoroughly.  As far as dressing up in period costumes, if you have something lying around the house, then throw it on.  Its not worth it to make a special effort to dress up for this though.  The production didn't show much effort so they shouldn't expect much effort from their patrons either.  Pass
author: Jim K.

description:
OVERFLOWING TOILET AND FLOODED BATHROOM WITH SF TOILET WATER ALL OVER THE FLOOR.....SO DISGUSTING 

EXTREMELY RUDE STAFF MEMBERS

DO NOT GO HERE....ESPECIALLY IF YOU ARE TRYING TO IMPRESS A DATE OR LOVED ONE.

READ THE OTHER REVIEWS ABOUT THE RUDE STAFF MEMBERS, SMALL SPACE, OVER CROWDED ENVIRONMENT, and WAY OVER-PRICED. 

       Way too expensive and my girlfriend and I were treated rudely.  They failed to seat us at our appropriate table we paid $200 for.  The guy Vinnie at the door failed to see our displayed flowers which were in plain site and sat  us  in the wrong room.  He said that we were seated based on the map we were given which is completely wrong.   He was a grumpy guy-read the other reviews about him.  I had to stand and my girlfriend had to sit on a crowded couch.   They tried to seat 4 of us on a 2 person couch with ripped cushions. There were people standing in front of us so we could not even see.
   After 45 minutes and $25 for 2 drinks we had enough of our obstructed view.  We went to the bathroom.  The bathroom was flooded.  When I flipped on the bathroom light switch I found myself standing in DIRTY SF TOILET WATER.  SO GROSS!!!!
     Then we went to the back room.  We were treated rudely by staff and discovered that there was a couple seated in our reserved table.  We had a reserved table we paid for which they failed to seat us at.  They asked the couple to move.  We finally made it to our correct seating after over an hour of disorganization and rudeness.
   READ THE OTHER REVIEWS ABOUT THE RUDE STAFF MEMBERS.  THEY ARE TRUE.
    Then we ordered 2 more drinks for over $25 and waited 10 minutes.   Our drinks never came. The service was HORRIBLE.  We left out of dismay and disgust.
   I wrote a letter to their Management asking for a refund.  They blamed us for failing to find our seats.  They said our flowers weren't visible which is FALSE.  They said they only offer refunds if the show is stopped.  THAT IS HORRIBLE CUSTOMER SERVICE.
    Spend your money elsewhere.
author: steven p.

description:
I'm surprised by the rave reviews, this was overpriced and underwhelming.  

Pros:
Feeling of intrigue approaching the event 
Actors are very talented, the singing was great 
Costumes by actors and guests, everyone was dressed to the 9s

Cons:
$80?  Really?  I've gotten cheaper tickets to lion king 
Disconnected acting.  I'm not sure how we could have followed he plot line-maybe chasing one actor around? There was so much happening in so many rooms, while at the same time so little happening at times.  I think there was a plot, but we never found it 
It was unclear where/when we could and couldn't move around. We spent a long time sitting on the least comfortable couch ever, squeezed 5 deep, with obstructed view because it seemed to be time to stay in one place. 
It got really hot, there were a ton of people, and there are safety/building code violations all over the place 
I haven't seen how much my drink cost yet. I'm scared to find out 

We didn't do the gambling, there wasn't space at the tables
author: L F.

description: Don't be misled by the positive reviews from a while back. My wife experienced this in March and thought it was fabulous. We saw it on May 29 and were very disappointed, as were our four companions.  My wife noted the cast had changed (except the lead female), there was no narrative about prohibition, a poor excuse for a comedy magician, worn out jokes (think Morey Amsterdam) a tyrannical room manager, Vinnie, who makes you move your chair 2" to make room for cocktail servers who don't use the space, and much, much more that made for a miserable evening for all. We left early and disappointed. Be warned!
author: Bob L.

description: What a fun time. From beginning to end, we felt as in a real speakeasy. The hush hush way you find the spot, the super strong cocktails, the cheesy dancers, the speedy magician, back room casino. Wow! I definitely recommend this show.
author: Sophie-Charlotte M.

description: We had an incredibly good time. The entire experience from beginning to end was great. If you are going to visit The Speakeasy be sure to dress appropriate to the era. It makes it a lot more fun and heightens the drama of the evening. You really get a feeling of being back in time to the 20's. Everything about this experience is well done; amazing performances, great music and an exceptionally well crafted venue.
author: Clayton M.

description: Best kept secret in SF! Such a fun and entertaining time. Never a slow moment. This is a must see/do.
author: Mike S.

description: Unbelievable. Don't ask questions, just put on your fanciest clothes and go.
author: Heather W.

description: Had an AMAZING time here last night! The show itself was well worth the price of admission. Some sort of "acting scene" was constant in all of the rooms of the establishment but it seemed like the bar itself was the place to be in my opinion. Would GLADLY go see this show again! Tell TOM at the bar I said Hi!
author: Bryan P.

description:
Immersive theater at its best! You have a full night to become your own character in the 1920s (costume wear is strongly encouraged!), and eavesdrop on a lot of action going on in a prohibition-era underground nightclub. Watch the cabaret, walk around the lounge, play a little blackjack, even peep into the chorus girls dressing room ... there will be scenes going on all around you. 

Definitely more of a show where you'll be watching things going on than a bar where you can chat with friends; however, the bar does deserve its own credit for making really amazing drinks while you're there!
author: Jane D.

description:
Really a lovely, unique, high-quality experience! Well worth the price  of admission and wait to see this play. Highly recommended! This is exactly what I always wanted "interactive theatre" to be. 

I struggled to piece together even a 1/4 of the sophisticated narrative but I still got a lot out of this play. I saw it more as a commentary on the time period filled with bigotry, prohibition, and sexual repression.  

Characters were fascinating and setting was well-done. We got the after hours pass which was really cool and had the opportunity to chat with the cast and learn more about the entire piece. 

WELL DONE BOXCAR!
author: Julie D.

description:
I should preface this review by saying I am a big fan of Punchdrunk Productions (one of the top innovators in immersive theaters) and as such have been to Sleep No More in NYC & Drowned Man in London several times.  I tried to not let my previous experiences with immersive theater influence my time at The Speakeasy but it was hard to do. That said my list below pretty much sums up my visit to Joe's Clock Shop.

Pros:
~Incredibly talented performers. 
~Gorgeous set design. The set designers and decorators did a fantastic job especially for the small space they had to work with.
~Voyeuristic area to watch all the happenings in the dressing room. Boxcar Theater should create more things like this room in Speakeasy as it really allows the audience to have insight into the lives and psychology of the characters.
~Great concept for an immersive theater experience but needed to be more fleshed out.
~Dedication to keeping the theme of a secretive speakeasy. I loved meeting in one location and having to find the second secret location. 
~Encouraging audience to dress in 1920's garb. It made the whole atmosphere so much more fun and authentic

Cons:
~Soundscape & design not fluid or fully conceived 
~It was hard to follow characters around as each one's storyline was stilted and not continuous. There was a huge reliance on the stage performances in the bar as opposed to character/story development.
~While the actors would interact with audience members, it was fairly jarring the way it happens and in some instances it seemed like the actor dropped character and was just chatting casually with me. I prefer Punchdrunk's method when it comes to 1 on 1 experiences, they're much more intense and intimate.
~Racist character. Seriously why? He doesn't add to the story and he also doesn't receive the social justice someone like that should if one were to make an example of him. We all know the 20's were racist, but we don't need that in our face.
~Over arching theme needs more fleshing out. There was too much reliance on the singing & dancing so the overall story got lost or put to the side.
~It was hard to tell who was a performer vs. who was an audience member since everyone was dressed up.
~The rules were not heavily enforced so there were times when audience members were having loud conversations with each other. That really took me out of the experience.

Summary: all in all I'm really glad I went. I had a lot of fun and so did my friend. Since it's Boxcar Theater's first attempt at large scale immersive theater I think they did a fantastic job. Even though I think there are things that could be improved upon, I think it's a great start at bringing immersive theater to SF and I hope Boxcar does more productions like this in the future. However what ultimately went into my rating was deciding whether or not I'd return for more visits like I love doing for Punchdrunk shows.  While I enjoyed my time at the Speakeasy, I probably won't return for anymore visits.
author: Monica C.

description: Great experience! A real San Francisco treat! The show is well done with lots of bits and pieces. You can be as involved as you want to be, or just sit back and watch the action. Lots to see, and lots to do, so well worth the evening spent!
author: Prexious R.

description:
Amazing! You are transported into the 1930's with amazing realness. You meet someone in a "neutral:" location and get directions. When you get there there's no one to help you find the door, and you seem to walk in on the shop keeper who looks hostile and wont assist you, so pay attention.
Once inside it feels very much like a speakeasy from the 30's. Actors sitting around you come alive and begin telling their story; the tapestry works so well.
Show up in as close to period dress as you can to keep the ambiance. 
The staff is friendly and helpful, the actors dedicated and the environment is a total immersion in a speakeasy of the period. Very well done!!
author: Gregory S.

description: If you are thinking about going to this just GO.  The show is fantastic, the cocktails are great and it is really worth it.  But if you do go please dress up and try to look in character, you'll look like a fool otherwise.
author: Mickey D.

description: Wow, what a trip!  We traveled back in time for a voyeuristic view of people living in the 1920's in SF.  It was an amazing voyage - I can't wait to come back and see everything I missed.  I would recommend period clothing as a way to further enhance your experience.
author: TBrian F.

description:
An amazing night out. 

The best thing I've seen in San Francisco, by far. 

Be aware this is an intense theatrical experience.  You are immersed in a theatrical event.  Some of the things you see are fun, funny.  Showgirls, drunk customers, gamblers, a slick magician that is fired for being late and drunk.  Other moments are hard to describe.  A shell shocked veteran from WWI that sees his fallen comrades walking by in gas masks.  A woman that finds her husband has gambled away the mortgage payment on their farm. It's heart wrenching.  

It feels like you are in the middle of a movie or play, observing from the inside.  

You get a text the day before telling you where to go. You will see others waiting around dressed up like it's 1920, so you don't feel so awkward.  Then you have a password to give.  They give you instructions on where to walk.  

They don't send everyone at once, so you're forced to figure out how to get in.  You find a dusty old clock shop and find your way in, a secret knock gets you through the door.  

In you walk into the most elaborate set.  It's 1923.  You walk into a speakeasy bar, with copper ceilings, a piano player, a casino, a vaudeville stage.  God knows how much this all cost.  

Because people come in costume, sometimes it's hard to tell who's part of the cast and who's a visitor.  Scenes happen all around.  You will want to follow a few scenes from room to room.  

The evening flew by.  At the end, our group compared notes. There is far too much to see in one visit.  Must go back again.  

I'm looking forward to bringing out of town visitors to this one.  I'm sure there is nothing like this anywhere in the country. 

An amazing plus.  I did not see one cell phone.   No cell phones, no one texting.  There are clear instructions to hide your phone.  It would ruin the illusion of someone pulled out an iphone.  The audience, for once plays along completely.  


Truly a must see.
author: David M.

description: The best night I have had in a long time. Well worth the price of admission.
author: Abbie K.

description: Due to weak writing it was hard to follow story threads or care for some characters.The way cast mowed me down in various rooms made me feel I was more in the way rather than a passive participant At times rooms could get over crowded because not much was happening in other rooms. No air conditioning so in over crowded rooms it could get stifling hot.
author: Ted B.

description: This was one of the coolest events I have been to in a while! Like stepping back in time to a REAL Speakeasy! Totally worth the money!! In fact, I want to go back!
author: Cindy M.

description:
(Oops! Accidentally cross-posted this also to Boxcar's yelp)

So much fun!!!
I'd seen Hedwig twice (and loved it!) and when I heard about even the idea of 'Speakeasy', I knew I absolutely had to go.
So, even though the tickets are not cheap by any means, they are totally worth it!
From the moment of meeting our 'contact' till the end (I won't give any spoilers), the whole night truly puts you in the time and spirit of the show.
The actors are totally top notch and my best advice to anyone going to the show is just follow the stories you really like. The fun (and kinda sad) part is, you won't get to see all the drama in one night. It's just not possible. Just find a couple of actors you resonate with and follow them around and get into their story. You won't be disappointed. Plus, being in (at least kinda) period wear will only help immerse you in the experience.
